tropeNotes:
[The Anti-Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAntiNihilist): The playable party collectively represents this in spite of all the suffering done to and by them in direct opposition to Kefka's [Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist) stance.
QUOTE **Kefka:** Why do people insist on creating things that will inevitably be destroyed? Why do people cling to life, knowing that they must someday die? ...Knowing that none of it will have meant anything once they do?  
**Terra:** Because it's not the end that matters! It's knowing that you have something to live for right now, at this moment! Something you've worked for... something that's worth protecting! As long as you have that...that's enough!

[Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment): This is basically *Character Development: The Game*. Terra allows herself to love others, Locke gets over his loved one's death, Celes learns to show affection like a human being, Cyan gets over his [Survivor Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorGuilt), and so on. Kefka, being a [Straw Nihilist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist) subject to [Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage), shows the dark side of this trope when his rampant thirst for destruction eventually leads him to the conclusion that everything exists only to be destroyed, preferably by him.

[Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack): As a precursor to the [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) that made a proper debut as a battle mechanic in the [next game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII), everyone  <sup>note </sup>  except Gau and Umaro; (they only execute when the Attack command is used, and Gau and Umaro don't have one)  has one super-strong attack they may perform randomly while in critical health.

[Empowered Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpoweredBadassNormal): It's a plot point. Aside from Terra and Celes, and later Strago, none of the Returners have access to magic <sup>note </sup>  ignoring [Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation) where many of their special attacks deal magical damage . Sure, their swords and shields and such are doing well enough to hold off the Empire for now, but they need magic of their own to get an edge and go on the offensive. Thus they acquire Magicite and begin to learn magic to combat the Empire's Magitek.

[Ensemble Cast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnsembleCast): A famous example in the series. Terra is *mostly* considered the main heroine by virtue of being the initial character and her personal character quest and backstory being critical to the first half of the game. However, she’s sidelined for the second half of the game and does not even need to be re-recruited. <sup>note </sup>  She still returns to guide the party out of Kefka's tower after defeating the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) regardless whether she has been re-recruited or not however.  Meanwhile Celes takes over the initial character for the second half and features prominently in the first, Locke plays as [The Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer) to Terra and Celes for much of the game, and Edgar and Sabin are important characters throughout the game to a lesser extent. Even with Terra, there is no one central character one can point to without being challenged.

[Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember): Exaggerated. Everyone but Celes, Edgar and Setzer is optional in the World of Ruin. Even major characters like Terra, Locke and Sabin are not required to finish the game, although Terra still come [Back for the Finale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackForTheFinale). A very common challenge run is "CES" - beating the game with just Celes, Edgar, and Setzer.

[Patrick Stewart Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatrickStewartSpeech): The whole party (minus the optional ones) give one to Kefka when he tells the party that [life is meaningless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrawNihilist). Suffice to say, he is not amused.
QUOTE **Kefka:** [Bleh! You people make me sick! You sound like the chapters from a self-help book!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpKirk)

tropeName: Sliding Scale of Idealism Versus Cynicism
tropeNotes: [Sliding Scale of Idealism Versus Cynicism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlidingScaleOfIdealismVersusCynicism): Kefka believes that life is meaningless because everything you create will eventually be destroyed and eventually you will die. Terra then states that the sum of one's life isn't what important; it's the day-to-day concerns, the personal triumphs, the celebration of life and love, and being able to experience the joy that every day of your life can bring.
[10-Minute Retirement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TenMinuteRetirement): All characters experience this to some degree in the World of Ruin, but Terra's is the most prominent.

[Ace Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot): Terra has access to more attacks in the Magitek Armor in addition of to the standard three elemental beams and one healing move. In the [Game Boy Advance version](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease) her class name is Magitek Elite.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): She was raised to be a living weapon. It shows; in terms of pure stats Terra is the best party member in the game.

[Action Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionMom): The children of Mobliz [see her as their Mama](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute) after their real parents were killed by Kefka's Light of Judgment.

[Adaptation Dye-Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationDyeJob): She's blonde in the artwork but has green hair in-game. When *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* came out, it stuck with the artwork, with only one of her three alternate costumes having green hair. *[Theatrhythm Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/TheatrhythmFinalFantasy)* made her blonde with a greenish tint. Finally, the iOS version kept the Amano design for her portrait, but dyed the hair green. She could be an honorary member of FFV's cast with all those alterations. *[Final Fantasy Brave Exvius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyBraveExvius)* splits the difference by having three different versions of her, none of whom share the same hair - the original version has green hair, her Trance form has bright pink hair, and her Magitek Warrior version has blonde hair.

[A.I. Roulette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIRoulette): Like all others in the Coliseum, but Terra is unique due to a strange bug with her Trance command: if it ends up getting used at random, the game will mistake her transformation gauge for a normal ready gauge, making her stand there and do nothing while it completely drains; her AI can freeze for up to *minutes* at a time.
[Amnesiac Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmnesiacHero): She can't remember her past until after the party escapes from the southern continent, about two thirds of the way through the World of Balance.

[Amnesiacs are Innocent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmnesiacsAreInnocent): Although there is some resentment towards her, the other party members make a point of telling those people that she shouldn't be held responsible for crimes she can't even remember committing.

[Audience Surrogate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudienceSurrogate): For much of the first half of the game, barring her lengthy absence at one point. She's caught up in two sides of a war with no understanding of what's going on or who's the side to fight for.

[Back for the Finale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackForTheFinale): If Terra is not re-recruited in the World of Ruin, she will still return after the final boss battle to guide everyone out of Kefka's tower.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): She has a very vulnerable and sweet personality, but she's an excellent battle unit.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): Used in conjunction with the [Mind-Control Device](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControlDevice), albeit very briefly at the beginning of the game.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): Ever since she was a newborn, she had to suffer under enslavement to the Gestahlian Empire. First, she was pretty much raised in a loveless environment. Then, Kefka discovers her and places a mind control device on her against her will, causing her to be forced to fry several Imperial troops alive under his command (50 soldiers, to be precise).

[Brought Down to Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BroughtDownToNormal): In the ending, magic and espers cease to exist, but Terra manages to hold onto her life and continues to exist as a normal human.

[Catch a Falling Star](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchAFallingStar): In the ending, when escaping Kefka's Tower, Terra's magical powers cease to exist, making her fall. The rest of the party uses the [Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship) to catch her.
[Child Soldiers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildSoldiers): Kefka installed a slave crown to control her, and she slaughtered scores of people in the Empire's name.

[Color-Coded Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedEyes): Her in-game sprite, though it's hard to tell, has green eyes, fitting perfectly with her mysterious and magical nature. Her *Final Fantasy Anthology* renders show them in full. Her (in-game) Esper form has [Red Eyes, Take Warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning)—at first played straight, then later subverted.

[Cute Monster Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteMonsterGirl): In contrast to later depictions, her Esper form in the original game is *not* this; Terra is unable to fully control herself in her transformed state even after her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment), and she is viewed as a terrifying and feral beast. The trope is played straighter in the iOS and Steam versions. While people still react to her Esper form with fear, her new portrait is quite alluring, and thanks to the art design of the new sprites she has an [Impossible Hourglass Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossibleHourglassFigure) with her breasts looking quite large when viewed from the side.

[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist): While central to the World of Balance section, she is optional in the World of Ruin section and the story no longer revolves around her. Celes then becomes [The Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHero) after the world is ruined. Terra does show up in the ending if not recruited however, but after the battle with Kefka.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): One of the most infamous cases in the series. Not only is Terra's hair a different color from concept art to in-game appearance, but her outfit is also substantially different.
    - Originally the design team decided to give Terra green hair because Celes was already blond. They also designed the character sprites *first* before handing off their work to Yoshitaka Amano which was the opposite order of the previous games. Tetsuya Nomura later stated in an interview that had Amano started with the character art, he would have always given Terra blond hair. - The green hair was her signature look up until *Dissidia*, which gave her blonde hair since everyone in that game was based mostly on their original concept art. Since then the blonde hair became the usual look for her, but the green hair continues to pop up, particularly in sprite-based cameos (but not just them). - Her sprite and SD artwork depict her with a red minidress, no tights, and a large pair of purple shoulder pads, while her concept art shows her in a red minidress with tights, no shoulder pads, and a pink cape. The original *Dissidia* based her design on her concept art and so went with the tights and cape, while her alt outfit removes the tights and gives her the green hair in reference to her game sprite. The arcade *Dissidia* gives her a more faithful variant of this outfit that removes the cape and adds the shoulder pads to complete the sprite-inspired look. - Later games after *Dissidia* tie her hair color and dress design together — the blonde hair goes with the tights and cape look, and the green hair goes with the no tights and shoulder pads look. Aside from the arcade *Dissidia*, *Record Keeper* includes both her designs, though with the green-haired one as the default and the blonde-haired one as the alt. Other games mostly stick to one design or the other now. - This also applies to Terra's eye color, which has variously been blue, [green](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurtainsMatchTheWindow), or purple. These days she's *mostly* settled on a purple-ish blue.

tropeName: Desperately Seeking A Purpose In Life
tropeNotes: [Desperately Seeking A Purpose In Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperatelySeekingAPurposeInLife): Once the crown is removed by the rebellion, Terra is left uncertain of what to fight for in a war where both sides believe she is a key asset.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): As soon as she recovers from whatever emotional trauma she was experiencing (amnesia and the power leak caused by emotional confusion), she becomes like this.
[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): She was born in the alternate realm of the Espers, so it's more like Doomed *Homeworld*.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): From Tina to Terra. The name "Tina" was used in Japan because it was an exotic name to them, but it's a more common name in the West so "Terra" was used for the same purpose.

[Easy Amnesia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasyAmnesia): By way of a [Mind-Control Device](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControlDevice). It's implied that it malfunctioned and damaged her mind when Tritoch attacked her, which is why she can't control her powers properly and can't remember her past.

[Elemental Personalities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPersonalities): She automatically learns fire spells. Initially this goes with the wild and potentially destructive nature of her esper side, but later in the game it reflects her warm, caring, maternal side.
[Emotionless Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionlessGirl): Her brief enslavement to the slave crown rendered her temporarily incapable of feeling emotions after breaking free of it.

[Fantastic Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticNuke): Gameplay-wise, she is the only one who can learn the [Ultima](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SphereOfDestruction) spell simply by leveling up. Of course, by the time she learns it, the entire party will probably know how to do it from using the Ragnarok magicite or the Paladin Shield.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Terra's "mixed" lineage, her feelings about it, the historical treatment of Espers and magic-using humans, and the reaction to her existence all have shades of this.

[Flashback Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashbackNightmare): When she falls down the cave and is knocked out, she undergoes a terrifying flashback revealing that she was placed under mind control via the Slave Crown by Kefka, forced against her will to burn fifty Imperial Troopers alive, and being present for Emperor Gestahl's war speech.
[Friend to All Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToAllChildren): She's quite taken with Relm. Eventually a town full of orphans latches onto her as their "mama."

[Gorgeous Gorgon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GorgeousGorgon): Her Esper form is seen as a monstrous and frightening thing that is barely recognizable as human. But when the children of Mobliz get over their initial shock of seeing the unknown creature and recognize their "Mama" in her, they crowd around without fear.

[Hair Color Dissonance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairColorDissonance): Her in-game appearance has green-hair. This has become a case of [Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist) thanks to *Dissidia*, where she has blonde hair as in her Amano artwork. Subsequent cameos use either color variably, since the green hair is still considered iconic.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): In Amano's artwork. Fits with her sweet, innocent and motherly personality.

[Half-Breed Angst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfBreedAngst): Terra is half-human and half-Esper. She has to contend with the fact that as half-Esper, she is viewed as a weapon of mass destruction that both sides of the conflict want to use.
[Half-Human Hybrid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfHumanHybrid): She's half-Esper, half-human. Makes up a good part of her character arc as she questions if she can fit into either world.

[Heal the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealTheCutie): Was enslaved from childhood under the Gestahlian Empire, and grows up without love and care. When she is recruited by the party, she has no memory of her past, and [struggles with the idea of love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatIsThisThingYouCallLove). However, her experiences with the party and discovery of a group of orphans turn her into a [Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear) and [Friend to All Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToAllChildren) with a great deal of hope and idealism.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Proficient with both swords and heavy armour.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Most of her weapons are swords, including her [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) in the ports, the Apocalypse.
[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): Early in Act 1, when it's brought up to her for the first time that she [may not be human.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap)

[The Heroine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeroine): According to [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), the game wasn't meant to have a main character, as the entire cast was given time to shine. Despite this, Terra is considered the central protagonist, especially after *Dissidia* made her the face of the game. She (with the [Magitek](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagiTek) armor) is depicted in the game's logo and the story begins and ends with her, essentially revolving around her for the first half and being mandatory for the ending sequence note  (If you skip recruiting her in the World of Ruin, she still rushes to the final dungeon) .
[High-Class Gloves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassGloves): She sports elbow-length gloves in Amano's artwork, fitting the delicate young lady archtype of the trope.
[How Do I Shot Web?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HowDoIShotWeb): It takes her some time to learn how to control her Esper side properly.
[Human Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanWeapon): She was used as one by the Empire. See [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy).
[Hypno Trinket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HypnoTrinket): The specific method behind her initial [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) state.
[Impairment Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpairmentShot): Gets quite a few of these in beginning due to amnesia, headache, exhaustion, and blunt head trauma before she passes out.

[Jekyll & Hyde](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JekyllAndHyde): During the game she uncovers her origin as the child of an Esper and a human, endowing her with a Super Form which is emotionally unstable but useful in battle.
[Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic): An attractive young woman with a slanderous reputation as a witch due to her highly destructive magical power.

[Last of Her Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHerKind): Kind of. After killing off Kefka, all of the Espers and magic disappeared from the world due to Kefka's death. The only reason Terra survived this was because she held onto something in the non-magic realm, thus making her the last Esper to survive (depending on how you define the phrase, considering that she is not an Esper anymore by this point).

[Late-Arrival Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LateArrivalSpoiler): Her being half-Esper was supposed to be a plot twist, but *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* and other crossover materials treat it as common knowledge.
[Letting Her Hair Down](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LettingHerHairDown): Removes her ponytail as she savors freedom during the ending.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): She and Celes are the only party members to learn magic naturally, her equipment selection includes everything from swords and heavy armor to rods and robes, her stats are all-around high, and her Trance increases all of her damage dealt. All-in-all Terra is a candidate for strongest offensive character in the game on both the physical and magical spectrums. Spinoffs actually forget this aspect, as a far greater emphasis is placed on her being a spellcaster.

[Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): Threaten her, enslave her, or try to kill her and she'll shrug it off. But if you have the bright idea to threaten her adopted children and attack her [True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions)... [we](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WreathedInFlames) [hope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage) [you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationSequence) [like](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) [fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire).

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Her English name is Latin for "Earth". Also, her Japanese name, Tina, was picked for more reasons than simply because it was an exotic name in Japan than in the West: Tina is the shortened version of Christiana, which is the feminine form of "Christian", and is also the name of an early saint who was tormented by her pagan father. Similar to that early saint, Terra was tormented by the Empire when they took her as a child.

[Military Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryMage): Terra starts the game as a slave soldier in the Imperial Army controlled by a [mind-control crown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControlDevice). She does not appear to have a formal rank, but is used by her Magitek-riding handlers as a [Living Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingWeapon).
[Mind-Control Device](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControlDevice): Kefka forces her to wear the Slave Crown, making her a puppet to his will.
[My Name Is ???](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyNameIsQuestionMarks): In the beginning, before the player names her.

[Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast): Terra's past aside from her origins is left almost entirely unexplored. We never find out the full extent of her servitude to the Empire - we know she wasn't consciously serving them, but what exactly was she used for? And as an even bigger question, what was her life like in between being kidnapped by Gestahl as an infant and being mind-controlled by Kefka as a young woman? It seems almost axiomatic that she was raised in Vector because Gestahl took her, but beyond that...

[Mysterious Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousWaif): Terra is an amnesiac ex-soldier who has the innate ability to cast magic, which was thought long-extinct. The other party members are quickly sympathetic to her and a good chunk of the first half is devoted to finding out her origins.
[Mystical Waif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysticalWaif): The only one anyone's met who can use natural magic (until Celes joins). Also the only living human/esper mix.

[Orphan's Plot Trinket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrphansPlotTrinket): Terra has a pendant which only appears as a key item and is only mentioned once in the story; her father gave it to her mother when they first met.

[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): Goes from the closest thing the game has to a central protagonist in the World of Balance to an [Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember) in the World Of Ruin. That said, she is brought back into the spotlight during the ending sequence.
[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): Her father is captured, and her mother is killed.
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): For the Mobliz orphans, whom she takes care of since all their actual parents died.
[Personality Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonalityPowers): Fire — wild, destructive, and hard to control, but if you can manage it it's also very warm and comforting.

[Phlebotinum Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhlebotinumGirl): She starts out under Kefka's mind control, and can use special functions of Magitek Armor thanks to her innate magic. The game starts with her being injured trying to escape The Empire and is rescued by Locke.
[Phlebotinum Rebel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhlebotinumRebel): She was a very valuable find for Gestahl until her Slave Crown came off.

[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Terra starts the game with Fire. She can also learn Fira, Firaga, and Meltdown naturally when she reaches certain levels if she doesn't already know the spells.

[Power Glows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerGlows): Some fans believe that this is actually the explanation for the [Barbie Doll Anatomy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarbieDollAnatomy) — the glow is so bright, it obscures her clothes (thus, she's still clothed and wouldn't be showing *that* anatomy). Amano's artwork has it as a case of [Fur Bikini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FurBikini).

[The Power of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfLove): In the World of Ruin, Terra stumbles upon a village of orphans whose parents were killed by Kefka and his [Light of Judgment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood). She starts looking after them, the children take to calling her "Mama", and these new feelings confuse Terra. She eventually realizes that it was love all along and that the future of these children is worth fighting for (she finally understood what General Leo meant about love). It's this, and her love for her true companions, that saves her from going poof like the rest of the Espers and the world's magic at the end.

[Progressively Prettier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProgressivelyPrettier): Her Esper form started out [like this in concept art](http://img4.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20120725071632/finalfantasy/images/thumb/d/d9/Terraesper.JPG/312px-Terraesper.JPG)◊, to [this portrait in the GBA version](http://img4.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20100925214708/finalfantasy/images/a/a7/Terra_esper_menu_portrait.gif)◊, to [this portrait in the mobile and Steam versions](http://img3.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20140219003154/finalfantasy/images/3/33/FFVI_Terra_Esper_Menu_iOS.png)◊.

[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): She is extremely wary of everyone she meets in the beginning because she's afraid they just want her for her powers. Although the Returners try to emphasize that they don't want to force her... [they still basically want her for her powers.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByNoIMeanYes)

[Psychosomatic Superpower Outage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychosomaticSuperpowerOutage): Espers are not naturally emotional creatures, y'see, which leads to her powers being sapped to pretty much nothing while she struggles with learning how to love in the second half of the game.

[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): After the battle in Narshe and her transformation into an Esper, Terra flies away as her powers go out of control. When her friends find her in Zozo, they discover that she still needs some time to get her head together. [The Bus Came Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBusCameBack) when the other Returners revisit Zozo after rescuing the Espers from Vector. Terra's regained her memories and made peace with who she is, and she rejoins the party.

[The Red Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRedMage): Her job name is "Magitek Elite", but she's also a textbook example of a Final Fantasy Red Mage. She uses swords and wears heavy armor, and she also has a mix of offensive and defensive magic.

[Reluctant Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantWarrior): Isn't much up to fighting in the World of Ruin during her [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment). Wasn't all that keen on the idea in the World of Balance, either.

[Required Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredPartyMember): For the trip to the Esper Gate, you're forced to bring her along since she's the one who actually opens it. She's also the first character you can play as, and isn't able to be switched out for quite some time after the game begins.
[Sorry I'm Late](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SorryImLate): In the second fight with Humbaba, she rushes in to help the party when half the team is blown out of combat and things look dire.

[Super Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode): Morph/Trance: It *doubles* her magical and physical damage, doubles her heals, and *halves* all the magic damage she takes (unless they are barrier-piercing spells). This ability is called the Boss Killer with good reason.
[Sword Beam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordBeam): Her Riot Blade [Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack) fires waves of energy at opponents.
[Team Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamMom): It doesn't quite show until later. This also naturally implies [another trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear) is waiting in the wings at any time.
[Technicolor Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TechnicolorEyes): [Some artwork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheWriter) gives Terra purple eyes, emphasizing her otherworldly appearance.

[Thong of Shielding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThongOfShielding): Usually it's hidden behind her sash, but it can be seen rather clearly in the modified 'knocked out' sprite after she's blown away from the Sealed Gate and less clearly in her normal 'knocked out' sprite.

[Token Flyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenFlyer): When she transforms into her Esper form she is the only character that can fly. Notably this means that the party has to find ways to get to her when she takes off without warning the first time. In the ending this allows her to get to the party when everyone else couldn't.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): Two times.
    - The first is after you clear the Magitek Research Facility and she rejoins your party. She has her [Super Mode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperMode) under control now, and she's also a few levels stronger than when she left. - Later, when she returns in the World of Ruin, not only is she more confident in who she is, but her Trance lasts twice as long.
[Tyke Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TykeBomb): She's been raised since she was a baby to be a living weapon for the Empire.

tropeName: What Is This Thing You Call "Love"?
tropeNotes: [What Is This Thing You Call "Love"?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatIsThisThingYouCallLove): A big issue for Terra. She struggles with learning how to love in the second half of the game. She finds it when she comes across a group of kids who don't have any parents.

[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): In the Japanese version and the [GBA](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/GameBoyAdvance) [version](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease), her mother, Madeline, spends the last moments of her life trying to keep Gestahl from taking Terra. In the English version of the original release she was already dying for unclear reasons and she willingly gave Terra to Gestahl and asked him to raise her. Gestahl knew she was [half human and half esper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfHumanHybrid) and decided to take advantage of this. Madeline immediately demanded Terra back, but she did not succeed and she eventually died soon afterward.
[Always Save the Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSaveTheGirl): Has this mentality due to the tragedy with Rachel. He was quick to save and accompany both Terra and Celes.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): A lot of Locke's compulsion to protect women comes from the fact that he's never forgiven himself for failing Rachel, since her amnesia and subsequent death led to his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD). As Celes rightly points out at the Opera House if you've taken her and Locke to Kohlingen, when Locke helped her escape from South Figaro, he was really saving Rachel.
[Badasses Wear Bandanas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassesWearBandanas): His fancy blue bandana is easily the most iconic thing about his character design.

[Bad "Bad Acting"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBadActing): His improvised on the spot acting after he, his comrades, and Ultros unintentionally hijack the Opera. The Impressario immediately comments on how awful Locke's acting is.
[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Calling him a thief *really* ticks him off.
["Blackmail" Is Such an Ugly Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackmailIsSuchAnUglyWord): How he feels about being called a "thief".
[Bodyguard Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardCrush): Locke swears to protect Celes because she reminds him of Rachel; he eventually falls in love with her.
[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): Though he doesn't show it, Locke is constantly haunted by his memory of Rachel.

tropeName: Changing Clothes Is a Free Action
tropeNotes: [Changing Clothes Is a Free Action](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChangingClothesIsAFreeAction): When in South Figaro, Locke can steal clothes from merchants and guards to disguise himself, and changes costume with a quick spin around.
[Chick Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet): Has shades of this with Terra and Celes. Sorry, Edgar!

tropeName: Cut His Heart Out with a Spoon
tropeNotes: [Cut His Heart Out with a Spoon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutHisHeartOutWithASpoon): In this case, he'll rip your lungs out if you keep calling him a thief (Ted Woolsey translation only).

[Devious Daggers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeviousDaggers): Locke's class "Adventurer" is modeled after tradition Thieves, thus he mostly equips daggers and short swords. His [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) in the ports is the Zwill Crossblade, a dagger.
[Dressing as the Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DressingAsTheEnemy): During his escape from South Figaro, Locke does this by stealing his enemy's clothes... *during combat*.

[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight): Played straight with Rachel. He couldn't save her from her accident and he wasn't in Kohlingen when [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire) attacked and killed her. Averted in the ending, when Locke saves Celes from an identical fall as Rachel had.
[Gentleman Thief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentlemanThief): He's not a thief, he's a treasure hunter! But either way, he's quite polite, chivalrous, and friendly.
[Guile Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuileHero): Tends to fight more with finesse than brute strength. He had to sneak out of South Figaro while it was occupied.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Aside from knives and boomerangs, Locke is capable of wielding swords, including the Ragnarok and Illumina/Lightbringer (which he can make good use out of if using Mug without draining MP to do instant criticals).

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): In the backstory, he went through a major one when he accidentally caused Rachel to suffer from amnesia and later when she died during the Imperial attack on Kohlingen.

[I Let Gwen Stacy Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILetGwenStacyDie): Twice over. He was too slow to keep her from falling down a cliff while exploring a mountain, which led to her contracting amnesia. [Her father called out Locke on this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero) and [Locke left Kohlingen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere). While he was away, she was killed in an Imperial attack, and since then, he fully [blames himself for](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault) once again not being there to protect her.
QUOTE **Locke:** I never should have left her side. I... I failed her...
[Iconic Item](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IconicItem): His bandanna, to the point Celes recognizes it as his when she sees a bird carrying it.

[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): He is ***not*** a thief, thank you! He's a treasure hunter. It's lampshaded in-game immediately after he makes the distinction.
QUOTE **Locke:** I prefer the term "treasure hunting"!  
**Arvis:** Ha! Semantic nonsense!  
**Locke:** There's a huge difference!
[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): How he felt about Rachel's amnesia. And he's not exactly wrong...
[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): Locke's reason for going against the Empire was because he was unable to save Rachel from being killed by them in a raid.
[Kleptomaniac Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KleptomaniacHero): He isn't fooling anybody with his Treasure Hunter speech.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): In sharp contrast to the [Fragile Speedster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FragileSpeedster) nature of most Thieves in the series, Locke's official job is "Adventurer". The difference is he gets greater access to heavy equipment and the top-tier swords for excellent offense and defense, and he keeps the expected high speed.

[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): His lover, Rachel, died in an Imperial attack many years ago, which spurred Locke to join the fight. Rachel rejected him after he inadvertently caused her to suffer from amnesia, and Locke blames himself for her death because he left her side and wasn't there to protect her.
[Love Hurts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveHurts): Locke can't forgive himself for what happened to Rachel until the Phoenix revives her and she convinces him otherwise.
[Loveable Rogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveableRogue): He seems to be the sort that makes a point of only stealing from his enemies.

[Master of Unlocking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfUnlocking): He frees Celes from her chains when he finds her in South Figaro, and is also the only party member who can unlock the doors in Narshe in the World Of Ruin. Notably, he's ones of the only thieves *in the entire series* who's ever seen actually picking locks.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - Locke **Cole** comes from a town called **Kohl**ingen, which is roughly equivalent to a town name like "Coalton". His first name [may be taken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName) either as a bad [Pun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pun) (what is it any self-respecting thief ought to be able to get past?) or a reference to the English philosopher John Locke, who espoused "government by consent of the governed" and the theory of Tabula Rasa — Locke is embroiled in a struggle against the [Evil Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilEmpire) and is particularly protective of the amnesiac Terra, due to his backstory. John Locke also wrote extensively about the concept of private property, which adds an ironic twist to the name. - Locke's last name of "Cole" may also be seen as a reference to the Cole National Company, known for manufacturing keys. Not only does Locke pick several locks during the game, he's pretty much the *only* thief we see doing this in the entire series.

[Mugged for Disguise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MuggedForDisguise): When Locke is trapped in South Figaro after the Empire takes over, he can steal the clothes from merchants and imperial soldiers to disguise himself as one of them. [Somehow, this works flawlessly](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaperThinDisguise).
[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure): Not being able to rescue Rachel from her accident and later death.

[My Greatest Second Chance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestSecondChance):
    - His dream is to find the legendary Esper Phoenix, which could perhaps restore Rachel to life. - As the party escapes Kefka's Tower, Celes drops the bandanna she found on Solitary Island and, as she runs back for it, the floor begins to collapse. Celes begins to hang onto an edge as Locke rushes to save her, and this time he refuses to let go.
[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero): Locke sees himself as this for failing to protect Rachel.

[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): Goes from one of the most consistently important members of the party in the World of Balance to an [Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember) in the World of Ruin.

[Precision F-Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecisionFStrike): In the *Advance* translation.
QUOTE **Locke:** Dammit! Got to get to Narshe on the fly.

[Required Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredPartyMember): Of all the playable characters, Locke is required for the most amount of time. He has his own scenario in South Figaro where he meets Celes, and he goes with Celes again after Zozo, when he comes along to protect her during the infiltration of Vector. He also accompanies Terra to Crescent Island due to his lack of trust in the Empire (which unsurprisingly turns out to be justified). Finally, if you want to fully explore Narshe in the World of Ruin, you need to bring Locke along to pick the doorlocks.
[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): He left his hometown after Rachel's accident.

[Stealth Insult](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthInsult): To Edgar. [Minus the stealth.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImStandingRightHere)
QUOTE **Locke:** Terra, please wait for me, and please, don't let a lecherous young king, who shall remain nameless, near you.

[Supporting Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingProtagonist): Has shades of this. While Terra and Celes take turns being the most central members of the game's [Ensemble Cast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnsembleCast), Locke is in the party from the beginning, receives the most instances of being a [Required Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredPartyMember), and has well-defined relationships with both of the aforementioned female leads.
[Take My Hand!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeMyHand): During the ending, he dives to grab Celes' hand as the floor crumbles behind them.

[Tritagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tritagonist): Locke is the third-most central character after Terra and Celes and is very prominent in the first part of the game. He's a required party member from the end of the intro up to the Siege of Narshe, then for the long trek to the southern continent, and then again for the expedition to Crescent Island. The only times he's not a required character is the journey to Zozo and the Cave to the Sealed Gate, but the former is also the time players will learn Locke's backstory if they bring him to Kohlingen. The narrative also treats him as the "leader" of the group on numerous occasions when they aren't formally meeting with Banon as Returners.

[Video Game Stealing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameStealing): His special ability is Steal, which consists of him leaping at an enemy's sprite to steal an item. Exclusively during his infiltration of South Figaro, he can also steal clothing from merchants or soldiers to use as a disguise.
[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Edgar, whom he pokes fun at and who mocks him in return.

[Annoying Arrows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnnoyingArrows): Averted; the Auto Crossbow is a [Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke) capable of [one-shotting entire groups of enemies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitMultiKill) for a long time.

[Automatic Crossbows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AutomaticCrossbows): His first (and [most useful, until it becomes obsolete](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke)) tool is the AutoCrossbow, which sprays all enemies in front of it with multiple highly accurate bolts.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): His ingame sprite shows him wearing a collared regal cape.
[Blinded by the Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlindedByTheLight): His Flash tool blares an array of light at enemies to damage them and inflict Blind.
[Boomerang Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomerangBigot): Edgar remarks that he doesn't like men because they don't listen, despite being a man himself.

[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): He's incredibly weird, he'll hit on any female of age, and [his icon depicts him with a goofy grin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArsonMurderAndJaywalking), but he created several advanced machines (including a castle that can submerge *into the ground* and emerge hundreds of miles away) and is a very good ruler.

[Casanova Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CasanovaWannabe): He hits on quite a few women throughout the course of the game, but he's successful with very few of them.
    - In-Universe as well: Locke and Sabin poke fun at him for this.
[Chainsaw Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChainsawGood): Edgar can use a chainsaw that sometimes kills the enemy in one hit or deal massive damage.

[The Chains of Commanding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChainsOfCommanding): After their father's death, Edgar and Sabin were to co-rule. Both wanted out, but at the same time didn't want to plunge the kingdom into chaos with their absence since there would be no heir. So they settled it with a coin toss. Edgar, being the protective brother he is, rigged the toss with a double-headed coin so it landed in Sabin's favor. Thus Sabin won his freedom while Edgar stayed in Figaro to rule alone.
[Chivalrous Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert): Or at least he tries to be. He's not nearly the ladies man he acts.
[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): Well, he is a king. Though he's not [The Dandy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDandy), he does dress far more nattily than most of the team.
[Deadly Gas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyGas): His Bio Blaster shoots a cloud of poisonous mist over enemies.

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke): Edgar is easily the strongest member of your team when you get him. His Auto Crossbow hits all enemies for more damage than a normal attack, at no cost or drawback, and will end most enemy encounters in one turn. Once you get to Zozo and learn magic, the Auto Crossbow starts to fade in power, but Edgar gets a selection of Disc Two Nukes with the Flash, Drill, and Chainsaw. By the time you get to the World of Ruin his tools largely fall off, but he has a good enough equipment set and rare access to spears that allows him to transition into a capable dragoon instead, preventing him from being a [Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter).

[Dramatic Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticIrony): In the World of Ruin, he masquerades as "Gerad" to take command of a band of thieves that escaped from Figaro Castle when it got stuck while submerging, so they can lead him through the caves they used to escape and he can get into the castle and fix the problem. Yes — the king of Figaro takes command of the thieves he imprisoned so they can break back into the castle they escaped from in the first place. Celes even [lampshades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) this.

[The Dutiful Son](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDutifulSon): Edgar willingly stayed behind to rule over Figaro when Sabin became so desperate to strike out on his own. Edgar eventually settled the matter with a rigged coin toss that allowed Sabin to leave with a clear conscience.
[Emperor Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmperorScientist): To a degree, as he is a rather skilled machinist.
[The Engineer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEngineer): Early localizations even have his class being Engineer.
[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): Invented a submersible land castle, and fights with mechanical tools in battle.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): He's quite an intelligent man and his Tools make him one of the most hard-hitting party members in the early game.

[The Good King](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodKing): It's quite apparent all of Figaro loves Edgar and considers him a great king. He's earned that sentiment. See [Insists on Paying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistsOnPaying) further down the page.

[Guile Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuileHero): All of his greatest moments involve outwitting someone rather than defeating them through strength. His own *twin* doesn't always know what he's up to.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Capable with both sword and spear along with heavy armor.

[Hockey Mask and Chainsaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HockeyMaskAndChainsaw): A random effect with the Chainsaw is for Edgar to don a hockey mask and attempt to deal a [One-Hit KO](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKO).

[The Infiltration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheInfiltration): In the World of Ruin, he adopts the [Paper-Thin Disguise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaperThinDisguise) of "Gerad" the Thief, worrying Celes who wonders if he lost his memory in the airship crash. In truth he is looking to prevent some bandits from looting his mobile castle, now stalled underground.

[Insists on Paying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistsOnPaying): If you have him at the head of your party while in Figaro Castle, the shopkeepers there will refuse to take any payment from their own king. Edgar insists ("Look, don't you have a family to feed? Just shut up and take it."), and the player gets a 50% discount as a compromise.

[The Jailbait Wait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJailBaitWait):
    - Regarding Relm: QUOTE **Edgar:** Not even a lady yet... Here's hoping you're still around in eight years, kid.
      - Averted in the Pixel Remaster translation, however. Instead, he just remarks that she's gonna break quite a few hearts when she's older.
    - There's also a little girl in Figaro to whom he apparently told he'd marry her when she's grown up.

[King Incognito](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingIncognito): Well, sort of. Celes (and probably the player, for that matter) figures out who "Gerad" is immediately, but he keeps up the charade. Fortunately, the criminals he's infiltrating don't know Edgar as well as Celes does, so the trick works on them.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Edgar is an English name that means "great spearman". Edgar [best weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) is The Longinus in the GBA, IOS, Android and PC ports, which is a Spear.

[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): His tools can dish out a lot of punishment— his Autocrossbow tends to hand out [One Hit Poly Kills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitPolyKill) on command, and the Drill is fantastic against bosses— but he's also very slow.
[Modest Royalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ModestRoyalty): Although he's clearly seen as king by his subjects, he avoids gratuitous special treatment by insisting he pay them for their wares.

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): At the very beginning of the game, Edgar and Figaro in general are officially aligned with Vector, though he's secretly working with Locke and feeding info (and possibly more material assistance) to the Returners. This ends shortly after the game's beginning, when Terra's appearance forces his hand and he makes his true allegiances official.

[Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity): When Kefka comes looking for Terra, Edgar feigns like he has no idea who Kefka is talking about, much less how Kefka expects him to know if she came to Figaro.
[Paper-Thin Disguise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaperThinDisguise): As the bandit leader Gerad, who looks identical to Edgar but with a [Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap).
[Poisonous Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoisonousPerson): His Bio Blaster tool will cause damage and has a high chance of poisoning any foe not otherwise immune to the condition.
[Rain of Arrows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RainOfArrows): His Auto-Crossbow shoots a storm of arrows, three for each enemy on-screen.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): He's more than willing to *personally* fight the Empire, and is one of the most powerful characters in the game for the first part of it.

[Reluctant Ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantRuler): He didn't particularly want to become the king, but it was him or Sabin and he knew Sabin wanted a life of freedom, so he took the burden for him.
[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): He is the king of Figaro, and one of your most versatile and most valuable party members.
[Significant Anagram](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignificantAnagram): "Gerad" in the English version; his alias is "Geoff" in the Japanese version.

[Small Name, Big Ego](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallNameBigEgo): A possible [subversion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). He's known as a flirt to his subjects (and the children want to marry him), but his banter to Terra and Celes is not reciprocated. If one pays attention, though, he only attempts it once as a kind of greeting and treats them normally from then on.

[Something Only They Would Say](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SomethingOnlyTheyWouldSay): When in his "Gerad" disguise, he tries to get rid of Celes while saying "My Lady". Celes responds that only Edgar would address her that way, and after a moment of silence, he declares that "My Lady" is a fairly common way of addressing someone. In the GBA translation, he refers to Celes as a "beautiful lady", saying that it's common courtesy to be polite to ladies.

[Status-Buff Dispel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatusBuffDispel): Edgar's Debilitator tool adds an elemental weakness to an enemy. Being completely random, you could easily end up with a fire-spitting dragon that's suddenly weak to fire, and you could reuse it until an enemy was weak to every element.
[This Is a Drill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsADrill): Edgar's toolset includes one massive power drill, complete with safety helmet.

[This Means War!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisMeansWar): Though he pretends to be an Imperial sympathizer, he uses Locke to coordinate with the Returners behind closed doors, which the Empire has gotten wise to. After Kefka torches his castle and Figaro is occupied, Edgar drops the charade and joins the rebels.

[Tough Leader Façade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToughLeaderFacade): It comes off when he talks to Sabin in the throne room. Beneath the noble king is a man who deeply misses his brother and has doubts over his own effectiveness as a ruler.

[Two-Headed Coin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoHeadedCoin): He uses such a coin in his childhood gambit with Sabin, betting which of them will leave the kingdom on the result, knowing that when it comes up heads Sabin will be able to live his own life guilt-free. If he's in the party when Celes is abducted by Setzer, it's strongly implied Edgar passes the coin on to her to use for her own bet, and then Setzer holds onto it. If Edgar and Sabin are both in the party, this will be depicted and Sabin will comment on it.

[With This Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithThisHerring): The King of Figaro has joined the party! That means lots of resources, right? Wrong, he comes with some basic tools and equipment. It is somewhat justified in that he spends most of the game on the run, or with his kingdom in shambles, and the shops in his castle are more than willing to give him free stuff. He simply insists on paying since they have families to feed, and settles at a 50% discount.
[Action Commands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionCommands): His Blitz attacks require controller inputs, but you can't use them until you've actually learned them in-game.
[Adaptation Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdaptationNameChange): His name is "Mash" in the Japanese versions.
[Animal Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalBattleAura): Tiger Break blasts a tiger-shaped aura of energy at enemies.

[Animal-Themed Fighting Style](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalThemedFightingStyle): Tiger style, at least in part. His style incorporates clawed gauntlets (with his [Infinity -1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityMinusOneSword) being the Tigerfang), he wears a fang necklace (and in concept art, a leopard-spotted sash), and his [Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack) is called Tiger Break. He's also compared to a bear more than once, and seems to have practiced some of his [wrestling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrestlerInAllOfUs) moves on *actual* bears.
[Bash Brothers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BashBrothers): When Edgar mobilizes Figaro against the Empire, Sabin comes out of seclusion to join his brother in the fight.
[Big Brother Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): Displays this toward Gau. When Gau's father fails to recognize his son, Sabin has to be restrained from decking him.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): At Mt. Koltz, in the World of Balance, Sabin comes in to save the party from Vargas in order to avenge his late master. He's also the first character to reunite with Celes in the World of Ruin; he's found single-handedly holding up a collapsing house in Tzen after the town gets razed by Kefka on a whim.
[Big Eater](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigEater): Cyan is taken aback at his big appetite and [noisy eating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JabbaTableManners).

[Big Little Brother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigLittleBrother): Played straight. He's the younger of the twins, and is supposed to be a tad taller than Edgar. He's also built like a padded bank vault due to years of training, whereas Edgar has a standard build.
[Boisterous Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoisterousBruiser): Built like a bodybuilder and has a happy, friendly personality.

[Charles Atlas Superpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharlesAtlasSuperpower): The dude can suplex a *train*, and manages to hold up a collapsing burning building for several minutes during a sequence later in the game.

[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): Despite spending the last 10 years away from Figaro and a royal lifestyle, Sabin still displays knowledge of things such as proper etiquette, [such as when he takes Gau to meet the man he thinks is Gau's father.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNsYd0IvjMg)
    - Then again, if you take him to the [Opera](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AtTheOperaTonight)... QUOTE **Sabin:** Huh? Why's everyone singing?

[Damn You, Muscle Memory!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamnYouMuscleMemory): In most fighting games, a special move input's direction is determined by the orientation of the character. This is *mostly* true for Sabin, as well, given most battles have him face towards the left, and so the [Hadouken-esque](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadouken) Aura Cannon is inputted Down, Down-Left, Left. The problem happens for the small handful of battles where he isn't facing to the left due to a back or pincer attack. Unlike in most fighting games, his commands are not inverted in these cases, potentially tripping up players used to them. The Pixel Remaster remedies this by displaying the inputs on screen as you input them instead of making you enter them from memory.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): Okay, so Figaro isn't all *that* decadent, but regardless, Sabin became highly disenchanted with royalty once it became clear that the court was more worried about who would succeed the king despite his supposed death at the hands of the Empire and made it abundantly clear that he wanted out.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): In a pair of artworks, Sabin has a beard, but not in the game, and according to some developers, it was because of the limitations with pixellated sprites. He does have a bit of stubble in Dissidia Final Fantasy Opera Omnia, though.
[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): Sabin dives off a raft to fight Ultros, only to be swept away from the rest of the party by the strong current.

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke): Sabin's Rising Phoenix can one-shot every battle when you get it. If you use him in battle consistently, you can easily end up one or two-shotting every non-boss battle up to the end of the Floating Continent.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): From Mash to Sabin, to give him a more royal-sounding name.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): After Vargas blows everyone except Sabin away, it becomes Sabin vs. Vargas.
[Gentle Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentleGiant): He's the largest human character in-game, and physically the strongest. He's also a [Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy).

[Got Me Doing It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GotMeDoingIt): After having a hard time trying to instruct Cyan on how to operate the Magitek armor:
QUOTE **Sabin:** Oh, for...! Thou art getting to be quite a pain in the— Great, now I'm even starting to talk like you!

[The Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeart): Sabin is the nicest, happiest and most selfless member of the team, and he's the one that goes out of his way to keep their hopes up. Celes is *overjoyed* to find him in the World of Ruin. See [Hope Bringer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopeBringer) below.
[Heroic Build](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBuild): The official art depicts him as muscular.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): While he doesn't actually canonically pull one in-game, his Soul Spiral/Spiraler Blitz can be used to this effect as it restores the other party members' HP and cures all their status ailments (even KO and Zombie), at the cost of Sabin's life (his HP goes down to 0 and he's removed from the battle). Unfortunately, the [A.I. Roulette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIRoulette) can make him use this during the one-on-one battles at the Colosseum, which causes you to lose instantly in a [Senseless Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice).
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Sabin's [Aura Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken) Blitz does Holy elemental damage.

[Hope Bringer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopeBringer): Sabin is the first teammate Celes finds in the World of Ruin. Sabin meets her with a laugh and with 100% determination to help her find the rest of their friends and afterwards go punch Kefka in the face. This positive attitude renews Celes hopes that they can still save the world.
[Hunk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hunk): Sabin shares his twin's good looks, but combines them with a tall and very muscular build.
[I Got Bigger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGotBigger): We're told that as a kid, Sabin was very small and had a weak constitution. After years of training, we see that's no longer the case.

[Informed Deformity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedDeformity): After a flashback to Edgar and Sabin as children, the person telling the story comments that at that time Sabin was small — even smaller than Edgar. However, the flashback used the same sprites as the rest of the game, when Sabin is a very large bodybuilder.

[Insists on Paying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistsOnPaying): Like his brother, the merchants at Figaro don't feel comfortable charging the prince for goods. Sabin forces them to accept payment because they need to support themselves.
[Kamehame Hadoken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken): Aura Cannon fires a large blue energy blast from his palms.

[Ki Manipulation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiManipulation): How his Blitzes are implied to work. With the exception of Raging Fist and Suplex/Meteor Strike, all of Sabin's blitzes use his magic stat to determine damage.

[Knight Errant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightErrant): Sabin, disgusted with the ordeal and wanting revenge on the Empire which was rumored to be behind their father's poisoning, left the castle but never strayed far from the kingdom. He trained for years with a martial arts master near South Figaro.

[Load-Bearing Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingHero): Two examples: When he holds up the collapsing house so that Celes can save the child trapped inside, and during the ending, when he saves his brother from some collapsing junk.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Invoked by his Blitz abilities, half of which deal magic damage, including his ultimate technique. Unfortunately for Sabin, he has among the worst base Magic stats in the game, and thus requires heavy Magic investment in order to get the most out of Blitz.
[Magnetic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagneticHero): Sabin is the one who actually gets three of the other heroes to join the Returner cause (Cyan, Shadow and Gau).
[Mr. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrFanservice): He's tall, strong, muscular, and has his brother's good looks.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): He's one of the nicer playable characters, as he saves Edgar and his teammates from Vargas at Mt. Koltz in the World of Balance and agrees to join them as part of the Returners shortly after. He even helps Celes save some people in Tzen from a collapsing house after Kefka's Light of Judgement blasts through the whole town in the World of Ruin.

[Not Distracted by the Sexy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotDistractedByTheSexy): When Cyan asks why Sabin is not affected by the infamous "licentious howler", Sabin attributes it to his years of ascetic training.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): His Rising Phoenix Blitz, which launches a barrage of flaming Sabin spectres at enemies.

[The Pollyanna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePollyanna): Not even [The End of the World as We Know It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEndOfTheWorldAsWeKnowIt) can ruin his chipper mood as Celes finds him holding up a collapsing house to save some people ravaged by Kefka's World Of Ruin. When Celes asks for his aid, he's ecstatic for the chance and actually restores Celes' failing faith that the world can still be saved.

[Rapid-Fire Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapidFireFisticuffs): His Raging Fist is a rapid series of punch attacks. His training with Duncan implies Phantom Rush is likewise this trope, but it's not clear what Sabin is actually doing when he uses it in battle.
[Razor Wind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RazorWind): One of his Blitzes, Razor Gale, sends slicing blades of wind at enemies.
[Rebel Prince](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelPrince): Didn't want to be king, preferring to focus on his martial arts.

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Despite not really being involved in the monarchy, he's still a prince, and quickly becomes a hero to rival any of the others. He states that the reason he started training in the first place was so he would be able to properly support Edgar.

[Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShirtlessScene): Occasionally, in official artwork and CGI animation. He'd be a [Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene) except for the fact that he *does* often wear a shirt (and his game sprites are always sporting one).

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): He's a walking shoutout to [fighting games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingGame) in general.
    - The first Blitz you learn is a picture perfect [Zanretsuken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ArtOfFighting), right down to the input command. - Guess what the input for [Aura Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KamehameHadoken) is? [Quarter-circle forward + A](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StreetFighter). - Also, more than one player has noted that his sprite looks like a super-deformed version of [Guile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/StreetFighterII).

[Some Dexterity Required](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SomeDexterityRequired): Sabin's Blitz techniques, while freed from many variables in [Fighting Games](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingGame), still require pulling off *[Street Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StreetFighter)*-esque input commands. However, the game is much more lenient, and not only can commands be given one button press at a time, but the more difficult ones (even the 360-motion Phantom Rush) can be performed with easy and simplified button presses. Just remember not to [reverse the inputs when you're attacked from the rear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamnYouMuscleMemory).
[Sorry I'm Late](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SorryImLate): Shows up when the party fights Vargas and saves them from him, fighting him as a [Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss).
[Stock Shōnen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StockShonenHero): His personality and fighting prowess make him fit this trope to a T.

[Supernatural Martial Arts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupernaturalMartialArts): From healing others to blasting his opponents or summoning firestorms, its easy to understand why he has the power to suplex a train.

[Suplex Finisher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuplexFinisher): An early-game Blitz, though it was retranslated to "Meteor Smash" for the GBA release. It does a ton of damage, though most bosses are immune to it, with the notable exception of the Phantom Train.

tropeName: Time to Unlock More True Potential
tropeNotes: [Time to Unlock More True Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeToUnlockMoreTruePotential): How he learns the Phantom Rush Blitz if he hasn't already learned it from leveling. Multiple rounds one-on-one with Duncan until he picks it up.
[Walking Shirtless Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingShirtlessScene): In the FMVs in the *Anthology* release, he's topless.

[Wolverine Claws](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolverineClaws): His weapons, being based on the Monk class. Notably this means he *avoids* the [Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk) trope many other Monks in the series subscribe too: Sabin needs weapons as much as any other party member.

[World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan): He easily takes World’s Strongest Man title. While other members of cast such as Terra and Celes are arguably more “magically powerful” than him, Sabin with just his [Ki Manipulation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiManipulation) and pure [Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk) physical strength is capable of insane feats like single-handedly holding up a collapsing mansion and memorably suplexing a [Ghost Train](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GhostTrain).
[You Shouldn't Know This Already](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShouldntKnowThisAlready): Even if you know the proper inputs, Sabin cannot use a Blitz until he actually learns it by leveling up.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): She was an Imperial General and is one of the most powerful characters in the game, with excellent stats, equipment, and natural magic.
[The Aloner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAloner): The possibility of being the last living person in the world after Cid's death is not a pretty thought.

[Anti-Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic): Her Runic ability causes magic to be diverted toward her. It also absorbs all damage and grants Celes the amount of MP it took to cast the spell. Unfortunately, it can also absorb spells cast by the party, meaning the player has to take turn order into account once they start training with Espers.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): Joins the Returners partially out of a desire to atone for her crimes as a member of the Imperial army. Her most specific described war atrocity was the burning of Maranda.

[Audience Surrogate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AudienceSurrogate): Celes assumes this role for the second half of the game, though it gradually gives way as she is rejoined with more of her friends. In the ending, she becomes the viewpoint character again for the most part, and expresses the most concern over Terra's disappearance. She, Edgar, and Setzer are the only characters you *must* have to finish the game.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): Her costume includes one, even though it's only present in the sprites rather than the artwork.

[Beautiful Singing Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautifulSingingVoice): She has a lovely enough singing voice to pass for a professional opera singer, and Locke refers to her performance as "wonderful".
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): She becomes this in the World of Ruin, when she recruits her party members back to fight Kefka and end his tyranny.

[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): It's clear when she joins the party that she doesn't have any experience with genuine friendship and affection. It gets even worse on the World of Ruin, where she may make a suicide attempt depending on the player's actions.
[Bungled Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BungledSuicide): In the World of Ruin, she attempts suicide by leaping off a cliff if Cid dies, but survives the fall.

[Celebrity Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CelebrityResemblance): In-universe, Celes resembles the opera singer Maria. Because of this, she becomes a drop-in replacement for the original singer, as part of a plan to obtain an airship. Setzer noticed the difference only after bringing her aboard.
[Concert Climax](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConcertClimax): She is a replacement singer for the opera and the target of Ultros' 4-ton anvil.

[Convenient Coma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConvenientComa): Celes was in a coma during the first year in the World of Ruin, giving plenty of time for the other party members to end up in the situations she finds them in.

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): During the Narshe-Opera House segment. While it is possible to go through this part of the game without Celes in the party, it is quite difficult, as it is one of the game's first increases in difficulty and enemies in Zozo can use magic to deal several hundred damage to the party and they otherwise have powerful physical attacks. Celes makes the going much easier since she can heal the party with her own spells and absorb some of the enemy's spells to restore her MP with Runic. By the time you go the Southern Continent and reach Vector, you've had enough time with Magicite to teach other party members some spells and won't need to rely on Celes anymore.
[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): Locke discovers her being held captive in South Figaro and waiting to be executed.

[Dark Reprise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkReprise): The Aria that Celes sings during the opera is repeated in her character theme/leitmotif... the night before Terra, Locke, Shadow, Celes, and Leo depart to Thamasa from the Albrook port, when Locke is trying to apologize to Celes for thinking that she was a traitor during the confrontation with Kefka in the Magitek Lab. It plays again when she attempts suicide by jumping off the cliff after Cid dies.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): At some point during the ransacking of Figaro, Celes was stripped of rank and imprisoned for treason, though we never learn why or by what methods Celes carried out the plot (although she reportedly balked at Kefka's plan to poison Doma).

[Defrosting Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceQueen): Joins the party with a very [cold attitude](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson), and then Locke gradually defrosts her. After the halfway point of the game, Celes becomes much more friendly towards the rest of the party and is altogether more optimistic and hopeful, to the point where she eventually becomes their unifying force. Edgar practically lampshades the trope in the SNES version, commenting that Celes is "cold as ice" when they first meet.

[Depending on the Artist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DependingOnTheArtist): Her Amano artwork depicts her as wearing a deep yellow uniform, her top variably being a corset with gloves or a yellow jacket with a purple/blue/black top. Her superdeformed art, as well as her in-game sprite, instead show her wearing a white cape over a green leotard. While the yellow outfit is not uncommon, in fan or official materials, it's the cape and leotard look that's stuck with her through her spin-off appearances.

[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): After Celes wakes up from a year-long coma to realize that the world really was destroyed, she's stranded on a deserted island with Cid, and everyone she knew is probably dead. Then, if you don't manage to save him, Cid's death completely shatters what small shred of hope was left in her, which leads to her attempted suicide.

[Deuteragonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Deuteragonist): To Terra. While Terra is the first character the player controls in the World of Balance and her story and character arc are central to its plot, Celes is the first character in the World of Ruin and she's the one who begins to [Put The Band Back Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuttingTheBandBackTogether) to strike back against Kefka. She's also a required character during the long, very plot-important infiltration of the Empire, and her appearance, abilities, and personality heavily present her as a [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) to Terra.

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): If Cid dies, Celes loses any hope for life and leaps off a cliff. She survives, however, and it's possible to avoid it by healing Cid properly.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): She appears in the background of one of Terra's flashbacks long before she appears in the main game as an Imperial General alongside Kefka and Leo.
[Emergency Impersonation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmergencyImpersonation): Celes has to impersonate Maria so you can find a way onto Setzer's airship.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Terra. They have nearly identical equipment save for one armor piece and their exclusive weapons in the GBA version, and their stats are very similar. Their contrasts include outfits (green dress with white cloak, red dress with pink cloak), abilities (Runic with Ice and defensive status spells vs Trance with Fire and offensive status spells), and personalities. Terra is innocent, naive, and idealistic while Celes is proud, snarky, and cynical.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): In both the artwork and her sprites. Noble and heroic traits included.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): Rivals Terra in her range of swords and heavy armour.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): Before the game begins, Celes burns Maranda to the ground; she's the reason that everyone is rebuilding the town when you visit. She resigns from the Imperial Army and is arrested for it afterwards, and after Locke rescues her in Figaro, Celes joins the Returners.

[Heroes Prefer Swords](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesPreferSwords): Almost all of her weapons are swords and her ability Runic must have a sword equipped in order to work. Her [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) in the ports is the Save The Queen.
