[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): Her natural magic includes the Blizzard line of spells, contrasting Terra using Fire. She's also seen as a bit of an [Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IceQueen), with the comparison directly made by Edgar.
[Identical Stranger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalStranger): Celes is the spitting image of the opera star Maria, but is implied to have barely an idea of who she is.

tropeName: I'm a Doctor, Not a Placeholder
tropeNotes:
[I'm a Doctor, Not a Placeholder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImADoctorNotAPlaceholder): Twice; first when Edgar remarks Locke is smitten with her during the group's trip to the cliffs above Narshe, and again when Locke suggests that she impersonates Maria to trick Sezter into leading their group to his airship.
QUOTE **Celes:** Thanks for your concern, but I'm a soldier, not some love-starved twit. (During the group's trip to protect the frozen Esper in Narshe) 
**Celes:** H-hold on here! I'm a former general, not some opera floozy! (During the group's trip to the Opera House)

[Improbable Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAge): She's only 18 years old and she already reached the rank of General, placing her in a similar level to the older Leo and Kefka whom are in their 30s. Her being a Magitek Knight skilled in ice magic may have something to do with it. It's also likely that her magical infusion process, having been perfected before her birth, allowed her to perform feats far greater than most soldiers.

[Incorruptible Pure Pureness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncorruptiblePurePureness): Only in the first translation, when her character quote describes her as having "a spirit as pure as snow." Kind of an [Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute) when paired with the fact that she is a former general who is infamous for torching a city.

[Instant Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstantExpert): When she's made to impersonate Maria, Celes not only manages to physically resemble her, but perform her part in the opera well enough to fool the audience and Setzer, despite apparently having no prior vocal training. The Pixel Remaster zigzags this somewhat in the Japanese and English versions of the opera: Uematsu specifically chose not to hire opera singers for those languages, so while still sung well, she's nowhere near as skilled as a veteran prima donna would be. Italian, Spanish, German and French play it completely straight, however.
[Lady of Black Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfBlackMagic): She's aloof, cold, and elegant, as well as a capable magic-caster who's skilled with ice magic.

[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): She's cool-headed, graceful and looks beautiful in an opera dress. She is also a skilled fighter who can use swords, knives and maces. Her artwork even shows her striking an elegant pose while holding a sword.
[Leotard of Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeotardOfPower): Her in-game sprite shows her in a green leotard.

[Lonely at the Top](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LonelyAtTheTop): Her character description in the GBA retranslation states this when it says, "None have ever truly known the woman beneath the general's guise..."

[Love Hurts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveHurts): If you let Cid die, Celes tries to kill herself. Before she throws herself off a cliff, she thinks about how everyone is gone; she specifically mentions Locke.

[Magic Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicKnight): Aside from a very small handful of exclusive items, Celes's equipment and stats are mirror images of Terra's in this regard. Interestingly, unlike Terra, spinoffs tend to not only remember but put more of an emphasis on her "knightly" abilities.

[Memento MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MementoMacGuffin): Finding Locke's bandana tied around a seagull is what gives her the hope to get off of the solitary island and start searching for her friends after her failed attempted suicide, if Cid dies. It appears again in the ending.

[Military Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryMage): She was infused with magic as a baby, after the process was perfected and no longer caused [insanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithGreatPowerComesGreatInsanity). She holds the rank of General in the Imperial Army. We never actually see her commanding troops, but dialogue tells us that she was in charge of the campaign to capture the town of Maranda. Besides the offensive and healing abilities that all mages in the setting share, she has a unique [magic absorption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterSpell) ability that makes her an effective [counter-mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic), although ironically this doesn't prove useful until she turns *against* [The Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmpire).

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): Subverted. Although Kefka implies that she was a double agent to the Returners, she actually did defect to the Returners, proving her loyalty by teleporting Kefka away before he could attack.

[Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast): There is very little backstory on how Celes rose to the rank of general, and even exactly what she did to get herself imprisoned or her motives for whatever she did. We know she was a bit fond of Cid even before the start of the World of Ruin, and she seems to find Kefka's methods distasteful from the start, but anything beyond that is left out.

[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero): It was nice of her to prove her loyalty to the Returners by turning the sword Gestahl gave her on Kefka, but she really should have killed him instead of just stabbing him and then backing off. The sight of his own blood and the sting of Celes' betrayal finally catapult him off the deep end, and gives him the motativation he needs to seizes the Triad for himself and kills Gestahl. Oops.
[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): She did something to be locked up as a traitor. Don't expect the game to ever explain what.

[Not So Above It All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoAboveItAll): For the majority of her screentime she's presented as nothing but serious. When forced into a role in the Opera however... She has a mild freak out and then proceeds to run face first into the nearest wall.
[Overranked Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverrankedSoldier): General at age eighteen. Try to figure that one out.

[Personality Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonalityPowers): Ice — cold, stoic and hard when the party first meets her, but gradually softens into a kind and compassionate woman. Again, [Defrosting Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceQueen).
[Pimped-Out Dress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PimpedOutDress): Worn when she was in the opera. The FMVs from the PS1 version lavish quite a bit of attention on it.

[Please Wake Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PleaseWakeUp): If Cid dies on Solitary Island, Celes thinks, at first, that Cid isn't really dead, but then she realizes he really is gone. Cue [Sparkling Stream of Tears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SparklingStreamOfTears) and attempted [Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide).

[The Power of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfLove): If Cid dies, Celes will see a pigeon on the beach with a blue bandanna wrapped around its wound. Celes recognizes it as Locke's bandanna and knows that he must be alive. Knowing that Locke is out there somewhere is enough motivation for Celes to leave Solitary Island and find her friends.

[Pure Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PureIsNotGood): In the first translation, she is described as having "a spirit as pure as snow." Up until her [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn), she was responsible for razing a city to the ground.
[Putting the Band Back Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuttingTheBandBackTogether): In the second half of the game, this is her quest.

[Required Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredPartyMember): With Locke after Zozo, she becomes the effective party leader to infiltrate Vector, since she knows the Empire best. She's also the first party member you get back in the World of Ruin, and for a short time, is the only playable character. She can only be switched out of the party again after getting the second airship.
[Second Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecondLove): For Locke, who eventually moves on from Rachel's death to be with her.
[She Cleans Up Nicely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheCleansUpNicely): When she poses as Maria, leading to an amusing moment of Locke looking her up and down and turning beet red.
[Sparkling Stream of Tears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SparklingStreamOfTears): She leaves tears behind when she leaps off the cliff if Cid dies.
[Spin Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpinAttack): Her Desperation Attack, Spinning Edge, has her leap towards enemies and spin in place with her sword out.
[Statuesque Stunner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StatuesqueStunner): Skirts the line at 5'8".
[Super-Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperSoldier): Augmented with Magitek so she could use magic.

[Tyke-Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tykebomb): The Empire infused Celes with magic at a young age, much like was done to Kefka, except it didn't cause mental instability in Celes since by that time the process had been refined. Kids have better mental rebound as well.
[Visible Silence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VisibleSilence): Her attitude towards Locke after the events in the Magitek Labs.
[Wink "Ding!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WinkDing): After she gets on Setzer's Airship, she flashes one to the player, since it's [All According to Plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllAccordingToPlan).

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): Though her portrait looks like a refined woman in her late twenties or early thirties, Celes is only 18 years old at the start of the game, and 19 years old when she wakes up on Solitary Island.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): He starts out as a mercenary who will work for anyone who can pay him without question. After being betrayed by the Empire he becomes a [Classical Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassicalAntiHero) — a stoic loner tortured by old memories.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): For the events described below under [Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill).
[Attack Animal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAnimal): Interceptor will often [intercept](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName) attacks meant for Shadow and then perform a powerful counterattack.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): Shadow only has Throw and no access to Ninjutsu magic like [Edge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIV). Even if [he could learn magic from Magicite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpoweredBadassNormal), his magic stats are low.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): When you defeat him in the Coliseum, your party asks him what he's doing there, and he explains that fighting is the only thing he knows how to do. He eventually agrees to join the Returners, mostly so he can put his skills up to the ultimate challenge. The reason for this isn't revealed until much later, and then only to the player.

[Canine Companion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanineCompanion): Interceptor, his loyal dog who follows him anywhere. It's when Interceptor *stops* his blind loyalty that something is up, namely, with Relm.
[Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack): Interceptor will occasionally block and counter attacks from enemies.

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): He was formerly a train robber, but he ended up chickening out of giving Baram a mercy kill, and it is hinted that his assassin/mercenary role was his way of running from his guilt for failing to do so.
[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): He wears all black, and is hinted to kill for money, but overall, he's not half-bad.
[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): It's the only way for him to atone for the spoiler mentioned in [Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill) below.
[Defeat Means Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansPlayable): In the World of Ruin. The only way to recruit him is to fight him in the Coliseum.
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): When the details of Shadow's five dreams and Relm's one dream are combined, it becomes certain that he is Relm's missing father.

[The Drifter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDrifter): In the World of Balance, sans the Floating Continent, Shadow can leave the party at set points in the story, or after he's earned enough money to earn his hiring fee.

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): It's implied in the ending that he deliberately stayed behind when Kefka's Tower was collapsing on top of him as a means to atone for failing to grant his partner-in-crime his mercy kill.

[Emotion Suppression](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmotionSuppression): He tells Terra that there are many people like him who have killed their emotions and warns her against forgetting that, implying that he thinks she'd be wise to not do the same.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): A programming quirk automatically gives Shadow the party leader slot when Kefka announces that he's going to poison Doma. Unless the player switches Sabin back in, this leads to *Shadow* expressing moral outrage over an inhumane atrocity.
    - Shadow agrees to escort Sabin past the Imperial Base free of charge and only leaves after Cyan shows up and can take over watching Sabin's back. Despite being a cold professional who works for pay even Shadow isn't heartless enough to leave a poor guy who washed up from the river in the middle of enemy territory on his own.
[Flashback Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashbackNightmare): In the World of Ruin, resting in any inn with Shadow in the party causes him to have post-traumatic flashbacks of his past.

[Game-Breaking Bug](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameBreakingBug): "Interceptor" is considered a permanent status effect for Shadow, and unfortunately, this makes it vulnerable to the infamous Rippler glitch. If an enemy snatches up Shadow's status and is then killed, kiss his beloved pooch good-bye outside of story sequences. (This has an equally odd aspect that if the same enemy uses Rippler again to target another player character, "Interceptor" will be transferred to that character instead.)

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): He'll join your party at a few points throughout the first half of the game, but will decide to leave either through random chance after an enemy encounter or at designated points in the plot. He can be recruited permanently if the player waits for him on the Floating Continent and bets a certain knife in the Coliseum.
[Heroes Love Dogs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroesLoveDogs): We know Shadow can't be *all* bad, because he cares for Interceptor and the dog is extremely loyal to him.

[I Cannot Self-Terminate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate): Was asked by his friend, Baram, to kill him, since he couldn't do it himself because of his mortal wounds. Clyde, as Shadow was known back then, couldn't do it and ran away.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): The Memento Ring, which is described as using the love of Relm's mother to protect from [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) attacks, can only be equipped by Relm... and Shadow.

[Ironic Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicEcho): More evident in the GBA translation, in which Edgar claims that Shadow would kill his best friend for the right price. As mentioned above, however, he couldn't.

[I Was Just Passing Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWasJustPassingThrough): He saves the party from the burning mansion in Thamasa, but when Strago thanks him for it, he claims he just wanted Interceptor back, who happened to be with them. This is implied to be [Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies).
[I Work Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWorkAlone): After the Fire incident in Thamasa, Shadow tells the rest of the party that he will look for the Espers in his own way.

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): If you leave the [Floating Continent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloatingContinent) without him. Also strongly implied to be what happens to him in the ending of the game if he survived the first act, [though his fate is never firmly established](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverFoundTheBody).

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): He alludes to this when he tells Terra that some people deliberately kill their emotions. Shadow himself is not a case, though, since it is shown that he cares for his dog, Interceptor.

[Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill): Shadow, back when he was known as Clyde the train robber, chickened out of mercy killing his wounded comrade Baram, and left him to be captured. He never forgives himself for it.
[Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet): Shadow's devotion to his dog Interceptor is one of the chief things that humanizes him.

[Muggle–Mage Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MuggleMageRomance): He is the father of Relm, whose mother is magical. Clyde (Shadow), on the other hand, is a [Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal). [Even his magic stats are low!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration)

[Neutral No Longer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeutralNoLonger): Shadow's first appearances show him mostly unconcerned with the conflict between the Empire and the Returners, only showing up [for a paycheck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyInItForTheMoney). However, [despite his claims to the contrary](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWasJustPassingThrough), he starts warming to the party's aims, and eventually Kefka and Gestahl's grand plan nearly kills Shadow, which results in him siding with the party (though, as noted under [I Work Alone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWorkAlone), that doesn't mean he works *with* them immediately).

[Ninja](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ninja): [Yup](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GratuitousNinja). He special ability is "Throw," which lets him use throwing stars, and his best weapons are knives. He's also [very fast and hits pretty hard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser), but his magic stats are quite low.

[No One Gets Left Behind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneGetsLeftBehind): If the player waits long enough, he will escape with the party on the *Blackjack*, and can be formally (and permanently) recruited at the Dragon's Neck Coliseum in the World of Ruin.

tropeName: Only in It for the Money
tropeNotes: [Only in It for the Money](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyInItForTheMoney): He loans his muscle to anyone who can pay his fee, then leaves when it pleases him or when his contract is fulfilled.

[Only Known by Their Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyKnownByTheirNickname): His real name is Clyde. "Shadow" was taken from the name "Shadow Bandits", a group of train robbers who he was a part of, along with his partner, Baram. By taking the name Shadow, he's making sure he doesn't forget his past.

[Past Experience Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PastExperienceNightmare): Leaving his only friend Baram to die. An act which still haunts him, as evidenced by *VI*'s surprisingly-chilling dream sequences that randomly crop up when Shadow uses a [Trauma Inn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TraumaInn).

[Permanently Missable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent): If you don't wait for him on the Floating Continent, Shadow perishes without you to help him escape. This also prevents Gogo from ever being able to use Throw.
[Right-Hand Attack Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RightHandAttackDog): His lone companion is his doberman, Interceptor, who sometimes attacks or guards against hits in battle.

[Screw This, I'm Outta Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere): In the World of Balance, if you recruit Shadow after Zozo and take him into the Opera House, he'll leave midway through the performance before Ultros arrives. The Impresario relays a message from him that he would have fallen asleep if he stayed another five minutes.
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Implied by several of his flashbacks and his overall personality.
[Shoo the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShooTheDog): He stays behind in the collapsing tower at the end, but doesn't want to drag Interceptor into it and tells him to go and live.

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): Shadow hardly says anything during the game and very rarely, if ever, shows any emotion.
QUOTE **Shadow:** There are people in this world who have chosen to kill their own emotions. Remember that.

[Throwing Your Sword Always Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowingYourSwordAlwaysWorks): While his Throw command is (probably) supposed to be used with just shuriken and scrolls, he can throw any weapon, including daggers, swords, spears, dice, brass knuckles, and magic staves.
[Train Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrainJob): He used to be a train robber who left his partner to die (or worse) when the posse closed in.

[Wild Card](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildCard): After completing the events at the Imperial Base near Doma, he may leave after any random battle (except aboard the Phantom Train), and he *will* depart at the cliffs shortly after the events of the Phantom Train if he hasn't left by then. The next time he meets the party he demands a hefty fee for his services, and will again be prone to leaving after a random battle. Averted in the World of Ruin, where he will stay with you permanently once he joins, and has his own spot on the airship.

tropeName: You All Meet in an Inn
tropeNotes: [You All Meet in an Inn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAllMeetInAnInn): Where you'll find him in the World of Balance. He's most often chilling in a bar and awaiting his next assignment.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): He is an optional character during Sabin's brawl with Kefka in Doma, but the Empire lures him away with a bigger paycheck. Gestahl's men backstab him on the Floating Continent, but he survives and pledges to make them regret it.
[You Shall Not Pass!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShallNotPass): He pins Kefka down long enough for the Returners to escape his wrath on the Floating Continent.
[Armor-Piercing Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingAttack): His basic Fang Bushido strikes enemies with a defense-ignoring blow.

[Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical): Cyan's Bushido abilites may seem impressive, but it takes so long for the gauge to fill up that it isn't really worth it unless you manipulate your turns so that you select their attacks first and charge up his Bushido while their attack animations are going off. The iOS remaster changes this so that he's a lot more viable—you pick Bushido, and get to pick which technique you want him to use from a list; when you do, his special ATB gauge appears and fills up (stronger attacks take more time, obviously), and you can have everyone else act as needed. Patience is still required, but it makes him much more viable. The Pixel Remaster removes the special gauge altogether and just has a sub-menu with all of his skills.

tropeName: Battle in the Center of the Mind
tropeNotes: [Battle in the Center of the Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleInTheCenterOfTheMind): Spending a night at the abandoned Doma castle in the World of Ruin with him as a party member triggers this as a sidequest.

[Boring, but Practical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoringButPractical): In earlier versions of *VI* it's considered more worthwhile to simply use Fang, and occasionally Flurry than most of his other Bushido skills.
[Chick Magnet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet): To Cyan's [own chagrin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwantedHarem), especially considering he was recently widowed.
[The Comically Serious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComicallySerious): He can be rather prudish and is frequently exasperated with Sabin's antics.
[Counter-Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack): One of his Bushido techniques, Sky, is a powerful single slash counter to an enemy that attacks him.

[Covert Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CovertPervert): If you look in Cyan's secret box at Mt. Zozo when Cyan isn't in the party, you can find several books, among them *[Machinery for Dunces](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParodiesForDummies)*, *A Pictorial Guide to Machines*, *Everything about Machines*, *Machines for the Mechanically Disinclined*, and *[Bushido in the Bedroom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreadEggsMilkSquick)*. Also, when you get to explore it during the [Battle in the Center of the Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleInTheCenterOfTheMind), it looks like his mind is populated by nude women and *[Femmes fatales](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale)*. This is especially curious as flashbacks show he was a fairly devoted husband (though obviously totally smitten with his wife).
[Crusading Widower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrusadingWidower): His wife and son were killed in the poisoning of Doma, and he joins the Returners' cause to avenge them.
[Cultured Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedWarrior): He's very skilled at making hand-crafted silk flowers, and he's also a talented poet.

[Curse Cut Short](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurseCutShort): When he first meets Celes, he doesn't know that she has defected from the Gestahlian Empire at first. He angrily confronts her, calling her an "Imperial b-" before the others intervene.

[Dead Person Impersonation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadPersonImpersonation): Writes letters and sends silk flowers made by him to the girlfriend of the dead soldier he met in Mobliz to make her happy.
[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): He's one of the few survivors after [Kefka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterClown) poisons Doma's water supply.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): From Cayenne to Cyan, due both to [Character Name Limits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterNameLimits) and Woolsey likely thinking that naming a serious, dour knight after a pepper made him difficult to take seriously. This was kept in the *Advance* retranslation despite the removal of the limit.
    - Similarly, since they don't have their own entries on this page, his wife and son had their original and Japanese-sounding names, Mina and Shun, respectively, to the rather Arthurian-sounding Elayne and Owain, in keeping with Cyan's adapted speech pattern.

[Everything's Better with Samurai](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingsBetterWithSamurai): His character class. He's also the only one in the game, although presumably there were others in Doma before they were killed. Strangely, however, Doma doesn't have any particularly "Japanese" stylings, which in the SNES version in particular made it difficult to realize just how Japanese Cyan is meant to be. At least in the Japanese version, the only other named citizens, his wife and son, had Japanese-sounding names.

[Failure Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureKnight): He is one of only two known survivors of Doma Castle. Even his wife and child die when Kefka poisons the river (the other on-screen survivor is an unnamed soldier who together with Cyan is searching the castle for more survivors. He is [never seen or mentioned again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse) after Cyan discovers his dead family and goes berserk).

[Flowery Elizabethan English](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloweryElizabethanEnglish): His dialect in localized editions. It was originally [Ye Olde Butcherede Englishe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YeOldeButcheredeEnglishe) in the original SNES translation, but made much more accurate in the *Advance* retranslation and every other retranslation onward.

[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): It's implied that Cyan was a good father to his late son. Owain adored him and internalized some of Cyan's values, such as the importance of protecting others. This gets carried forward into *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*'s Hien, who is basically an [Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy) of Owain/Shun, save that he was able to actually grow into the man Owain should've been able to (and had to watch *his father* die at the hands of an Imperial general instead).

[Gory Discretion Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoryDiscretionShot): His Limit Break "Tsubame Gaeshi" cuts to black as he leaps at the opponent and slices them. We don't see what he does, but it deals a lot of damage.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): To Elaine for many years before she was killed during the siege of Doma. In a flashback, Cyan tells her that he loves her.
[Heartbroken Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeartbrokenBadass): He was devastated by the deaths of his wife and child.
[Heavy Equipment Class](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeavyEquipmentClass): A master of the katana along with being able to wear heavy armor.
[Heroic Build](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBuild): The official art depicts him with an athletic build. One art piece in particular depicts him as top-heavy.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): It's implied that [his assault on the imperial camp after the poisoning of Doma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge) was Cyan attempting to cripple their army in a last stand. He calms down somewhat after meeting Sabin and agreeing to join the Returners.

[Hopeless with Tech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessWithTech): He cannot work any of the technology he comes across to (at one point literally) save his life. A manual found in the World of Ruin implies he's trying to get over it.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling):
    - Due to the [character limit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterNameLimits). Even with the *Advance* version's larger character limit, his Woolsey-localized name is still kept. - Incidentally, Kaien (海燕 in kanji) is a real male name that was used during the [age of samurai](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JidaiGeki) (meaning "sea swallow", which *also* puns on this character's [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) being the "Tsubame Gaeshi", or Swallow Reversal technique), and is meant to be a kind of antique, old-timey name. While the Japanese *Final Fantasy VI* and its reference material consistently renders his name as Cayenne (カイエン in katakana), *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV): Stormblood* includes an NPC named Kaien (カイエン) in direct reference. This has led to some suspicion that, despite the consistency otherwise, the *VI* character was intended to be "Kaien" the entire time and the transliteration of the name from katakana somehow got confused with the pepper.

[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): He blames himself for not stopping Kefka from poisoning the river, even though there's no way he could have known the bastard was going to do it, or that Kefka was even there at the time. Wrexsoul and the Dream Stooges gleefully exploit his [Survivor Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorGuilt).

[Jidaigeki](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JidaiGeki): In Japanese, he's pretty much a walking ball of Warring States tropes (he talks like an old-timey samurai which inspired his English speech pattern, he's got an old-fashioned name if you render it in kanji, and his limit break is *literally* [Sasaki Kojiro](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/SasakiKojiro)'s Swallow Reversal technique, which puns off his name).

[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): Befitting his class, Cyan is the exclusive wielder of katanas (labeled "knives" in the SNES/PSX versions), including his [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) in the GBA version, the Zanmato.
[Lantern Jaw of Justice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LanternJawOfJustice): Not as exaggerated as other examples of this trope, but there it is.
[Magically Inept Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicallyIneptFighter): His Bushido techniques and his normal attacks do quite a bit of damage. However, his magic is among the game's worst.
[Manly Facial Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyFacialHair): Cyan has a magnificent mustache, the only party member in the game to have one too.
[Mighty Glacier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MightyGlacier): Very impressive physical stats like HP and Strength. Not so impressive Speed.

[Old Retainer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldRetainer): Identified as such in-game, he is fiercely loyal to Doma and her people and would do anything to protect them. Cyan's canonical age is 50, and the King of Doma in his final moments says Cyan has served the realm "since my father's days.

[Possession Equals Mastery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PossessionEqualsMastery): Zig-zagged. When Cyan, Sabin, and Shadow steal three mechas from an imperial camp, Cyan has no idea how to pilot his mecha and accidentally rampages through the camp. After a few moments, he gains control of his mecha and uses it in battle.

[Required Secondary Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredSecondaryPowers): Before the mobile version of the game, Quick was the only way to use his higher end Bushidos without turning the entire party into sitting ducks.

[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge): The death of his wife and son, not to mention his entire kingdom, sends him into one, as he charges toward the Imperial camp.
[Rōnin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ronin): Of the reluctant variety, due to the death of the King of Doma, his liege-lord. He's deeply unhappy about it, blaming himself for his lord and family's deaths.
[Samurai](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Samurai): His character class and way of battle, and he has the noble and honorable personality demanded of bushido.

[Samurai Ponytail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SamuraiPonytail): His black hair is quite long and tied in a ponytail, being shorter than Edgar's but longer than Sabin's. And like said above, he's a samurai.

[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): The events at Doma leave him broken. His sidequest in the World of Ruin involves putting him back together as his problems have made him prey for mind demons.
[Single-Stroke Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SingleStrokeBattle): His ultimate Bushido, Oblivion, cleaves enemies apart in one stroke.

[The Strength of Ten Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStrengthOfTenMen): His character description in the SNES version describes as having "[the courage and strength of a hundred men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExaggeratedTrope)." He lives up to that description when he single-handedly kills the attacking Imperials and later storms their camp alone and holds his own with some help.

[Survivor Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorGuilt): The core of his character arc. Cyan is the only surviving member of the kingdom of Doma, and was powerless to save his people from Kefka's poison. He is wracked with grief over this loss, believing he failed as a samurai and has lost his honor. Coming to terms with this pain and letting go of his guilt is the pinnacle of his [Character Development](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDevelopment).
[Suspiciously Specific Denial](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySpecificDenial): When Sabin confronts him over his aversion to machines aboard the Phantom Train, Cyan panics and denies it.

[This Is Unforgivable!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsUnforgivable): Cyan literally says this after the poisoning of Doma and then rushes into the Imperial Camp roaring challenges and killing soldiers left and right. Appropriately, the song playing during this scene is called "The Unforgiven."

[Walking Techbane](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingTechbane): He is not good with machines and has a pronounced aversion to them, such as his first time using the Magitek Armor in the Imperial Camp, where he ends ups doing *spastic right-hand donuts before accidentally trampling over several Imperial soldiers*. He *tries* to learn more about how to use them over the course of the game, though.

[Watching Troy Burn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WatchingTroyBurn): Shortly after repelling an initial Empire attack, Cyan has to watch nearly everyone in his home castle drop dead from poison, including his king as well as his wife and son.

[Ye Olde Butcherede Englishe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YeOldeButcheredeEnglishe): He speaks like this in the original SNES version, but it was then retranslated into *actual* [Flowery Elizabethan English](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloweryElizabethanEnglish) in the GBA version and every other version since then.

[Animalistic Abilities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalisticAbilities): Gau learned to fight by [copying the attack patterns and special abilities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCopying) of the monsters and animals that migrated to the Veldt by leaping into their packs and living and hunting alongside them. He also makes it easier for Strago to learn several of his Lore spells, as he can simply cast them during some of his Rages.

[Awesome by Analysis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeByAnalysis): It's how he learned to fight, and how he learns his Rages. Gau lives on the Veldt, where monsters from around the world migrate, and he has lived his life watching them to the point that a bit of time observing the animals there allows him to copy their attack patterns and special attacks.

[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): Being able to survive in a fierce wilderness and kick the ass of monsters bigger than you since you were barely old enough to walk should qualify anyone as this.

[Bare-Fisted Monk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BareFistedMonk): Gau doesn't equip weapons, but his base attack power is far higher than any other character's. When physically attacking, he uses a weapon that mimics the attack animation of the monster he's copying, but this doesn't actually increase his attack power. When copying some monsters, or when he counterattacks with the Black Belt before you choose a Rage, Gau will simply punch the enemy.

[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): When Rage is initiated, although unlike the Berserker status in the series, he has a 50-50 chance of either physically attacking, or using the special move related to the specific "Rage" he's using. As an added bonus, if you cast the Berserk spell on him after he's in Rage mode, he will still have a 50% chance of using his Rage's special attack, but his regular physical attacks will also get a power boost.
[Cloudcuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cloudcuckoolander): He doesn't seem to have any interest in the larger situation and is primarily just concerned with his friends.

[Cool, but Inefficient](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolButInefficient): Gau's rages require him to visit the Veldt, and know exactly when to visit the Veldt. He also requires a guide to know which rages do what and there's a ton of them. And in the time you've taken to really get the most out of Gau, you've already slaughtered the enemy team with Ultima or another powerful magical attack. Gau never loses power or use, but the question then becomes "Why use him when I got about 6-7 other members who can do what he does without losing control of him?

[Crutch Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrutchCharacter): Gau is one of the strongest party members in the World of Balance if you understand how Rages work and know which ones do what. He can be casting Level 2 magic before the rest of your party has touched their first Magicite shard, and he has other powerful abilities too. However, later in the game the power of his Rages in proportion to normal magic and other special attacks begins to level out. By the end of the game his Berserk status when using Rages heavily hampers his effectiveness, though he remains capable, especially as a [Tank](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall). Some of the Rages he can get, like Magic Urn, grants protection from instant death and other status immunities, absorbing most spells and having a 50% chance of casting Cure 3/Curaga on the party.
[Death by Childbirth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByChildbirth): The reason his father went mad and abandoned him on the Veldt.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Once you gain access to the *Blackjack*, his plot relevance pretty much becomes nil, since the potential exists to easily leave him on the Veldt from that point on. He doesn't even have any sort of special method of being re-recruited in the World of Ruin; Cyan informs the party that he saw Gau on the Veldt as usual, and you can easily grab him there, no strings attached.

[Difficult, but Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DifficultButAwesome): He is either the worst or most-broken character, depending on how surgically you use him. Gau's Rages really demand you use a guide to figure out what each one does, or you have to rely on trial-and-error or just memorization

[Disc-One Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke): When you first pick up Gau, it is possible to get him to learn Rages that include some absurdly powerful attacks for that stage of the game, such as Fire 2, Blaze, Wind Slash and Fireball. Later in the first half, he can learn spells that you don't learn until well into the 2nd half, like Quake and Gigavolt, the equivalent to Bolt 3/Thundaga. Or, if you prefer for him to handle support, he's the only one capable of using Life3/Reraise in the first half of the game. And did we mention that absolutely none of them cost MP?

[Ditto Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DittoFighter): His time on the Veldt allows him to understand and copy the moves of monsters on the plain (and by proxy, any regular mob in the game). He fights using the patterns of defeated monsters, even copying their elemental affinities and innate statuses like Float.

[Fairy Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FairyBattle): When fighting on the Veldt, Gau is liable to appear at the end of fights to rejoin your party after using Leap. However, you'll need to have an open spot in the group for him to fill.

[He Cleans Up Nicely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeCleansUpNicely): An optional sequence late in the game allows the party to reunite him with his father, who fails to recognize Gau but momentarily snaps to his senses to compliment him on being a well-bred young man.
[Hulk Speak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HulkSpeak): Frankly it's impressive that he's able to speak with *any* kind of coherence, given that he was abandoned as a newborn.

[Innocent Fanservice Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentFanserviceGirl): Some Amano concept art showed him *naked* (but not showing parts). This would have been entirely logical for a [Wild Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildChild) in [Real Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealLife). The in-game graphics and the more well-known art show Gau wearing his more familiar animal skin clothes.
[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): Thanks to Cyan's speech patterns, he picks up the idea Sabin is named "Mr. Thou."

tropeName: In the Dreaming Stage of Grief
tropeNotes: [In the Dreaming Stage of Grief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheDreamingStageOfGrief): After his mother died giving birth to him, his father was driven to insanity and threw him out into the wild. When the party presents Gau to him late in game, the crazed old man denies having a son and relates the story of his dream in which a "demon child" was born.

[Lethal Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): He's completely uncontrollable and all of the Rages he actually starts with suck, which makes many players dislike him. If you train and equip him correctly, though, he can be *extremely* effective.
[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): Perhaps to make up for his uncontrollable nature and inability to equip weapons, Gau has all-around great stats.
[Makeover Montage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakeoverMontage): During the World of Ruin the party gets him cleaned up to meet his father.
[Nature Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NatureHero): A very friendly one. He was raised entirely isolated from people and his skillset is based around wild monsters.
[Nerf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Nerf): Later ports of the game took away his ability to wear the Merit Award, which is needed for one of the setups involving him.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Despite his lack of social skills, he's pretty friendly and only playful at worst. When he thinks he has upset Cyan, he seems deeply concerned about it until Sabin sets Gau straight. Gau also prevents Sabin from slugging his father even though he probably deserves it.
[No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell): Gau acquires the status and elemental immunities of whatever monster he's copying. These also stack with the protection he gets from his equipment.
[No Social Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSocialSkills): Of course, being [Raised by Wolves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RaisedByWolves) will do that.
[Offing the Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffingTheOffspring): His father, driven mad by grief of losing his wife, threw his own son to the Veldt.
[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): His mother died when he was born, and his father was driven insane from her death and threw Gau into the Veldt.
[Power Copying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCopying): His Rages let him copy the attack patterns of enemies the party has defeated.
[Raised by Wolves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RaisedByWolves): And other miscellaneous animals on the Veldt.

[Scarily Competent Tracker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScarilyCompetentTracker): You can make him Leap in one battle and then travel halfway across the Veldt, and Gau will still rejoin you in a later battle. Your location on the Veldt is irrelevant. No matter where you are on the Veldt, Gau *will* find you as long as you've got an open space in the party.

[Stone Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall): Late in the 2nd half, after he's no longer outstripping everyone in terms of magic capability, he excels as a Tank, as he has really high defense when equipped with the Snow Scarf and his best equipment and some of his Rages like Magic Urn make him really hard to kill as it absorbs most magic, has instant death protection and casts Cure 3/Curaga 50% of the time.

[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): Has no personal connection to the main plot; he just follows Sabin and Cyan after befriending them and apparently likes everyone so much he just decides to keep with them.
[Through His Stomach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThroughHisStomach): How he's initially recruited - Gau will run from Sabin and Cyan after a set time, but if they give him Dried Meat, he'll join them.

[Utility Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtilityPartyMember): Late in the game he's really better as a Tank or a assisting party member, able to cast support or healing spells and have his Rages give him status immunities.
[Verbal Tic Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTicName): Gau is actually a Japanese onomatopoeia for roaring.

["Well Done, Son" Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellDoneSonGuy): Zigzagged. The Crazy Old Man [doesn't have a son](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveNoSon), but says that Gau is good enough to make whoever his father is proud. When he recalls that [crazy reoccurring nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatWasNotADream) of abandoning a demon-child on the Veldt, Sabin wants to deck him. Gau stops him and says that he's happy his father is still alive.

[Wild Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildChild): Deconstructed, as the game actually looks into the rather terrible circumstances that would produce one, and how completely socially inept such a person would be.
[Wild Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildHair): Obligatory for the above trope, his hair is green and very long and unkempt.

[Actually Pretty Funny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActuallyPrettyFunny): How he gets recruited into the party: you'd think that a flashy gambler (who has scars on his face to show how serious he is about it) would go ballistic after being fooled by Celes using a [one-sided coin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RefugeInAudacity), but, no... he quickly accepts the fact that he, "the world's greatest gambler", *has been outsmarted for once*.
QUOTE **Setzer:** Ha! How low can you stoop? ...I love it!

tropeName: And Now You Must Marry Me
tropeNotes: [And Now You Must Marry Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndNowYouMustMarryMe): He is in love with the opera star Maria and plots to kidnap her, only to abduct Celes instead when she masquerades as Maria in order to sneak the Returners aboard his craft.
[Animal Stampede](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalStampede): His aptly named Chocobo Stampede Slots attack.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Wears a long black coat. Fitting given he's reputed to be a flashy show-off by the Impressario.

[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): An unorthodox example, now that Cid has temporarily relinquished the role. After the *Blackjack* snaps in two when Kefka pulls the Triad out of alignment, Setzer leads the party to Darill's tomb so they can find a new mode of transport.
[Cast from Money](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromMoney): The game's Gil Toss user if you equip him with the appropriate relic.
[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): The Blackjack, his massive airship that's also a flying casino. And later, he gets the Falcon.
[Critical Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CriticalFailure): His failed Joker's Death Slots kills off the party for getting it wrong.
[The Dandy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDandy): When they try to make Gau presentable, Setzer tells the shopkeeper to get him some clothes like the one he's wearing.

[Death Dealer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathDealer): Setzer can obtain a set of cards called "Trump Cards", which have a small chance of landing a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill). Not to mention his gambling motif and the fact that his Desperation Move is literally a volley of magical playing cards. Later translations call them the "Death Tarot", making it even more literal.
[Death from Above](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathFromAbove): His Dive Bomb Slots calls the *Blackjack* in to rain explosives on enemies.

[Death Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathSeeker): There are strong implications (more blatant in the Advance version) that Setzer doesn't really care if he lives or dies, accompanying the Returners initially as either something to give his life meaning or as a grandiose way to face his death. In the World of Ruin, Setzer reveals this was a consequence of losing Daryl when he was younger.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): In the SNES version, he's initially wary of the Returners' cause since the empire has allowed him to make a fortune as a free-roaming gambler, but they convince him to help them after he learns the true goals of the empire (or Kefka in particular). [In reality,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope) this is a [translation error](https://legendsoflocalization.com/final-fantasy-vi/opera/#setzers-famous-mistranslation) — in the Japanese version and as corrected in *Advance*, he realizes the empire has actually been *bad* for business.
[Drowning My Sorrows](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrowningMySorrows): How he spend his time after his [Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD) in the World of Ruin.

[Flechette Storm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlechetteStorm): His cards. Give him a specific relic and you got a Gil Toss ability where he throws money. His [Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack) is just to throw cards at enemies [three times](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfThree).
[The Gambler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGambler): He's a firm believer of luck and will gamble everything, even his own life. He also fights with darts, dice, and playing cards.
[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): His face is covered in scars from gambling sessions that went wrong.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): In World of Ruin, he seemed like had lost hope after 'losing his wings'. Only after Celes gave him an ear of [Get A Hold Of Yourself Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetAHoldOfYourselfMan) did he finally unearth the Falcon.

[Hope Bringer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopeBringer): In the World of Ruin, he restores hope to his friends by resurrecting the Falcon. The airship allows them to reunite the heroes and challenge Kefka.
[Improbable Piloting Skills](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobablePilotingSkills): This man caught a falling person with the bow of his airship. A zeppelin-shaped airship.
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): He fights by throwing playing cards, darts, and dice at opponents.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): Setzer's introduction involves a plot by him to [kidnap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveYouNowMyPretty) and [forcibly marry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndNowYouMustMarryMe) opera singer Maria. No one ever calls him out on his behavior and he's never punished for it; he just decides Celes is a better prize then Maria, and then he loses his coin toss to her and decides to go with it.

[Lethal Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): Normally, Setzer struggles to find a role, since his usual weapons do middling damage and often have weird effects (like instant death, which sounds great but always fully heals undead), his magic is unremarkable, and Slots aren't typically so great. But - but! - Setzer has *two* ways to break the game. Either equip him with Loaded Dice and the Offering, for 4x attacks that are not subject to the damage penalty from the Offering, or learn to manipulate the Slots, allowing for target-all instant death on demand.
[Light 'em Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightEmUp): His Prismatic Flash Slots attacks enemies with [rainbow beams of light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingsBetterWithRainbows).
[Luck Manipulation Mechanic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LuckManipulationMechanic): His supposedly random Slots are infamously easy to rig.

[Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone): Unfortunately. He's not particularly good with magic, not particularly good in combat, and worse than the all-rounders at both those things. His Slots ability has a lot of potential uses, but other characters have a similar "toolkit" mechanic without having to get through a buggy slot machine that mostly yields Lagomorphs. He also has [Late Character Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LateCharacterSyndrome) to deal with.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): 'Gabbiani' is Italian for seagull. Like seagulls, Setzer is a migratory person. "Setzer" may be translated from German as "someone who places", which might hint to his nature as a gambler, i.e. someone who places bets.

[Memento MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MementoMacGuffin): The Falcon once belonged to his beloved, Darill. She ended up dying in an airship accident, and he laid the Falcon to rest at her tomb until he decides to fly it once more in the World of Ruin.
[Money Mauling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoneyMauling): His standard attack is replaced with Coin Toss/GP Rain when he equips Heiji's Jitte relic.

[Rocks Fall, Everyone Dies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RocksFallEveryoneDies): Setzer's Slot command can pull this off in two ways. One is to get 7-7-Bar on the machine, which [kills the entire party](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill). The other is getting three bars to trigger a random Esper summon. If the game randomly decides to summon Crusader when your party is still weak, you'll be wiped out.

[Sky Pirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkyPirate): Only very slightly. He doesn't attack and rob other ships (mainly because he has the *only* airship) but he's definitely not a strict adherent to the law.
[Summon Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic): Two of his Slots results. Three bars brings up a random Esper, while three silver dragons will always summon Bahamut.

[Take My Hand!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeMyHand): Does this to Terra when the Apocalypse ripped the *Blackjack* into two before both of them falling, making this gesture somewhat pointless and to Celes in the ending scene if you didn't re-recruit Locke in the game's second half.
[Thrill Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrillSeeker): Conned into helping the rebels and delighting in their trickery, Setzer entrusts his life to them as little more than another bet.

[We All Die Someday](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeAllDieSomeday): The *Advance* translation adjusts his reckless gambling into a symptom of this trope. Setzer will ante up his own life because he knows sooner or later his number is going to come up, so he might as well have fun playing the odds and winning until it does.
QUOTE **Setzer:** When things fall, they fall... Life's a game of chance. You play your cards, and Fate plays hers...
[White Hair, Black Heart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhiteHairBlackHeart): Downplayed. He has long white hair and is the most amoral member of the party, but he's still clearly a hero.

[10-Minute Retirement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TenMinuteRetirement): Once a monster hunter, he's settled down in his old age to raise his adopted granddaughter, Relm. When Terra and Locke come to the village seeking the Espers, Strago is eventually roped into helping them. He later gets conned by his well-meaning war buddy to go hunt down a monster which eluded them so long ago.
[Anti-Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic): His Force Field Lore chooses a random element and negates all damage and magic of that type.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): His wind-elemental Lore, Aero, creates a gale-force wind that manifests tornados around enemies.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): In the World of Ruin, he is brainwashed into joining the Cult of Kefka after the seeming death of Relm, but she snaps him to his senses.

[Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp): By the time you recruit him, the World of Balance is almost done, and you get him for an hour or two before you move on to the Floating Continent. As a result, you'll have a hard time teaching him even the most basic spells, and in the World of Ruin, he'll be lagging behind everyone else still learning them while they've moved on to the World of Ruin Espers and their end-game magic.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): A wisecracking and nervy old Blue Mage. At age seventy, he's one of the oldest characters in the series.

[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): It is strongly implied that the reason he joined the Cult of Kefka was because he felt he had nothing left to live for due to believing that Relm had died. Thankfully, when Relm reveals her survival, he wakes up.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): His name in the original Japanese is Stragus. It was changed to Strago due to [Character Name Limits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterNameLimits).

[Eccentric Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EccentricMentor): To the party when they enter Thamasa. He pretends he has no idea what espers are or what "magic" is, but later proves himself a powerful mage.

[Elite Tweak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteTweak): Having problems learning some Lores? Use other's characters' abilities to make the process easier; Gau and Relm can use many Lores via their own abilities, and even Setzer can use one if you're very lucky with (or rigged) his Slots.

[Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn): He loses track of Relm during the apocalypse. Believing her dead, he allows the Cult of Kefka to brainwash him and take him in. He snaps right out of it, though, once he realizes that Relm is alive.
[Fixed Damage Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FixedDamageAttack): 1000 Needles deals exactly 1000 unblockable damage to enemies.
[Go to Your Room!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoToYourRoom): Tries this on Relm frequently. Since Relm is quite the [Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint), it never works.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): His Transfusion Lore has Strago give up his life to restore an ally's stats.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Due to the [character limit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterNameLimits), the last letter of his Japanese name "Stragus" had to go. Early fan translations had it as "Stragos".

tropeName: I Will Only Slow You Down
tropeNotes: [I Will Only Slow You Down](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWillOnlySlowYouDown): In the ending, he decides to stay behind because of this trope. Relm doesn't listen to a word of it.

[Mage Species](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageSpecies): Strago is descended from the original magi from the War of the Magi and thus has the ability to use magic passed down through his bloodline. * [Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): His initial Lore, Aqua Breath/Aqua Rake, and later Tsunami/Cleansweep, attack enemies with water. The former manifests as an explosion of bubbles, and the latter calls in a tidal wave.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Strago **Magus** is one of only two player characters that can cast magic spells innately from birth (Celes was infused with magicite as an infant).
[Miniature Senior Citizens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MiniatureSeniorCitizens): He's only 4'11".

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): Strago's Lores are genuinely impressive, except he's in one of the games of the franchise where magic is ridiculously overpowered. As a result Strago's unique skillset is outdone by the normal spells everyone can learn including him. Their sole advantage is they ignore Reflect, but by the time you get to areas in the game where that's a problem, you've probably picked up magic that ignores Reflect like Meteor or Ultima.

[Power Copying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCopying): As a Blue Mage, he learns Lore skills by watching someone else use them. As mentioned in [Elite Tweak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteTweak), this includes player characters.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesImDoingWhatsRight): Thamasa forbids its citizens to openly practice magic, **especially** when outsiders are around, to avoid their powers being found out. When Relm is trapped in a burning house, Strago decides he doesn't care and begins using magic to try and put out the flames in full view of Terra and Locke.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): If you equip him right, he can do a lot of damage, but as you might expect he can't take a whole lot of punishment. Not surprising given his age.
[Art Attacker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtAttacker): Relm has the Sketch ability which lets her use the target monster's special abilities.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): She's a cute little girl who can paint a portrait of you that kicks your ass.
[The Beastmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBeastmaster): The Fake Moustache relic changes "Sketch" to "Control", letting her directly take command of enemies.
[Bratty Half-Pint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrattyHalfPint): She has no problems sassing her elders even when they include kings and former Imperial generals.

[Canine Companion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanineCompanion): Interceptor is friendly towards her, despite Shadow's claim that he isn't friendly with strangers. If Shadow wasn't rescued in Floating Continent, Interceptor will become Relm's protector in the battle, instead. This is another hint to Shadow and Relm's relationship.

[Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp): Like Strago, she joins very late in the World of Balance part of the game, so you'll have to spend a lot of time teaching her the basics while everyone else is getting stronger. However, unlike her grandfather her explosive magic stat growth gives you an incentive to look past this and spend the time farming her up anyway, as she can quickly outperform party members who are much higher level and more developed than her.
[Ditto Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DittoFighter): Her magic manifests in the ability to paint living portraits that attack their subjects.

[Flashback Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashbackNightmare): If Shadow dies on the [Floating Continent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FloatingContinent), you will not find Shadow in the Cave on the Veldt, but instead Relm, who will have a dream of her own that ties in to Shadow's five [Flashback Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashbackNightmare) scenes. But without [Save Scumming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SaveScumming) to many hours earlier in the game, Shadow's fifth dream and Relm's dream cannot both be viewed within the same playthrough.

[Gamebreaking Bug](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GamebreakingBug): In the 1.0 edition of SNES version, the Sketch command has a good chance of crashing the game if used on the wrong enemies. At worst, it can irreparably bork your save. On the other hand, judicious use with save states can lead to breaking the game in the other direction, [as demonstrated by this tool-assisted speedrun](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tIjJZNM3rDA&feature=youtu.be&t=2h58m49s). It can also net you multiple copies of items you're not supposed to be able to get multiples of, like Illuminas and Atma Weapons. The 1.1 revision of the SNES version patched this glitch, as did the PS1, GBA, Virtual Console and SNES Classic Edition versions.
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): Her primary weapons are paint brushes.

[The Jailbait Wait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJailBaitWait): Joked with by Edgar, who cracks he hopes she's still around in eight years. Though given what had just happened, this could also be taken as an incredibly dark joke that he hopes she's still *alive* in eight years. This is changed in the Pixel Remaster to commenting about how she's going to be a heartbreaker when she grows up.
[Jumped at the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpedAtTheCall): She joins the party just for its own sake, and is indignant at the suggestion she be left behind because of her age.

[Kid With The Remote Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KidWithTheRemoteControl): The Fake Moustache relic allows her to control monsters. The success rate of this ability can be boosted with the Hypno Crown.

[Lethal Joke Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LethalJokeCharacter): Relm doesn't have very good Strength or weapon options, and Sketch is either bugged or mostly useless. But she has the highest base Magic stat in the party (even though she doesn't initially know any spells), and her equipment spread also provides her with a lot of magic-boosting options. So with a bit of training and Esper use, she can become *very* useful. (Notably, she has the highest natural magic stat in the game, although it's quite likely that players will have boosted Celes' and Terra's stats to comparable levels with Espers by the time they recruit her).
    - While Sketch is mostly useless, the Fake Moustache relic changes it into Control, which is an incredibly useful ability that trivializes a lot of usually difficult encounters.

[Little Miss Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LittleMissBadass): She proves her worthiness by following the party through a dangerous cave and defeating Ultros. Mechanically, she's also a walking explosion once kitted out with magic properly.
[Mage Species](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageSpecies): Relm is descended from the original magi from the War of the Magi and thus has the ability to use magic passed down through her bloodline.

[Manic Pixie Dream Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManicPixieDreamGirl): Though Strago is often exasperated with her devil-may-care behavior, Relm is always there when the old man needs a kick to get going

[No One Gets Left Behind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneGetsLeftBehind): She has none of it when Strago said to leave him and carries him on her back instead. She's also quite insistent that she not be left behind during her ending segment if she is recruited back into the party but Strago isn't.

[Orphan's Plot Trinket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrphansPlotTrinket): The Memento Ring, which protects from Instant Death with the power of her dead mother's love. Notably, Shadow can also use this, because he is her father.

[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): Relm's mother is said to be dead in the inventory description of her [Orphan's Plot Trinket](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrphansPlotTrinket); her father, on the other hand, is never directly mentioned. Indirectly, there's a million and one hints that he's Shadow. The developers confirmed this in an interview. There was going to be a scene between Strago and Shadow confirming his relationship to Relm, but it was dropped.
[The Pen Is Mightier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePenIsMightier): Statistically not, but what she draws with it is possibly mightier depending on the subject.
[People Puppets](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeoplePuppets): When given the Fake Mustache relic, she can Control enemies.
[Raised by Grandparents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RaisedByGrandparents): Her adopted grandparent. Her mother died, and her father ran away to be a ninja.
[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Her threats to Strago about "painting his picture," which, given her abilities, is an actual threat.

[Sir Swears-a-Lot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SirSwearsALot) : In the original Japanese script she is surprisingly foul-mouthed for one so young. This was [Bowdlerised](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bowdlerise) in the Woolsey translation, due to Nintendo's censorship policies at the time. Later translations emphasize the snark and sharp tongue.

[Squishy Wizard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SquishyWizard): Like her grandfather, Relm is a powerful magic-user. However, whereas Strago was so old he had a hard time taking blows, Relm is so young she has a hard time taking blows.

[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): She's an excellent mage and a fun character, but she doesn't have a huge amount of relevance to the plot and mostly comes along because she demands to.

[Troubling Unchildlike Behavior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TroublingUnchildlikeBehavior): [Played for Laughs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedForLaughs). Despite being only ten, Relm has a foul mouth, is extremely rude, and has a sharp wit she uses to make a lot of snarky remarks. Sabin and Edgar are both surprised to see someone so young acting in such a manner.

[Useless Useful Spell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UselessUsefulSpell): Save for a few specific instances, the Sketch algorithm falls into this for three reasons. Firstly, it is incredibly glitchly and can corrupt your saves and crash the game. Secondly, it has the monster's stats, rather than Relm's. Thirdly, many elemental or status attack will be likely nullified or even absorbed since monsters are commonly immune to their own status and elemental attacks.
[Whatevermancy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Whatevermancy): In the Japanese and GBA version, Relm is a "[Pictomancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtInitiatesLife)".

[Advertised Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AdvertisedExtra): Featured heavily in the English SNES version's advertising, being the only character to appear on the cover, *and* the only one to appear in the TV commercial and magazine ads. Even so, he's irrelevant to the plot, being an optional character who's easily missed, and his only other appearance is in a brief tutorial sequence near the beginning.
[Animal Stampede](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnimalStampede): Wombat and Boar Brigade both unleash those critters on enemies.
[Badass Adorable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassAdorable): A moogle that can be equipped to be a dragoon.
[Battle Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleCouple): One of the other moogles in his party (during the Narshe Mines fight), Molulu, is Mog's girlfriend/mate.

[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): Like Gau, Mog becomes uncontrollable for the rest of battle or until killed once he uses a Dance. However, each Dance includes four possible attacks with various effects, so he's a bit more versatile about it than Gau.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): His Wind Slash and Sandstorm Dance attacks.

[Breaking the Fourth Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakingTheFourthWall): Mog is your guide during an early part of the game where the main characters are [separated into three groups](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoLinesNoWaiting), and he explains that you must pick a group in order to progress the story.

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): He's one of the Moogles who help Locke protect an unconscious Terra from the Narshe guards trying to capture her near the beginning of the game.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): His base weapons hit hard and his Dances have great offensive potential, but they also include powerful healing and buffing abilities.

[Cute Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteBruiser): With proper Esper stat training and the right equipment, Mog can slaughter enemies. And he waves to you before he does it!
    - He can become an even better dragoon than Edgar, who was created to *be* a dragoon. He has better armor, being able to reach the [armor cap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cap) with no cheats and no bug exploits, he's the only character to be able to reach it.
[Dance Battler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DanceBattler): Learns various dances related to the environment; each has various attack and support techniques.
[Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt): His Rock Slide and Cave In Dance attacks attack enemies with falling boulders. However, they aren't actually Earth-elemental.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): Mog is briefly playable during the [Multi-Mook Melee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiMookMelee) at the start of the game; he can't be formally recruited until much later.

[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): Has only a few lines of dialogue in the whole game, none of which indicate much of a personality, is the only non-secret party member without a World of Ruin sidequest, and to top it all off, he doesn't even have a unique sprite, looking just like every other Moogle in the game.

[Friend-or-Idol Decision](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendOrIdolDecision): Between Mog and Lone Wolf. Choose Mog and you get yourself an [Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember). Choose Lone Wolf and you will get a Gold Hairpin which halves MP cost. Since it's not the only Gold Hairpin in the game and one of his Dances can be [Permanently Missable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent) if you don't recruit him (at least in the SNES and Pixel Remaster versions), the choice is obvious.

[Geo Effects](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeoEffects): How he learns his dances, by fighting on different terrains. Also used in said dances where he attacks with nature-themed abilities; his Dances basically combine the Geomancer (magic determined by the current surroundings) and Berserker (losing control of him once he starts dancing) jobs from *Final Fantasy III* and *V*. He also has 100% success in using a Dance native to its surroundings.
[Healing Hands](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HealingHands): Mog has *several* dances which have restorative effects, including Sunbath, Forest Healing, Tapir, Raccoon, and Arctic Hare.

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): In the World of Ruin, the party finds him alone in the cave where the other Moogles used to live, staring at a wall (the item found by inspecting said wall, a memento from his girlfriend Molulu, implies he was staring at it). Then the party arrives and Mog is overjoyed to see some of his friends are still alive.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): His Dance attack Avalanche is ice-elemental, and sends a wave of ice and snow over enemies.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): In the opening sequence, you get help from eleven Moogles. Oddly, one of them learns an ability while fighting while the others have none, and the others cannot have their equipment modified while the same lone Moogle lets you equip and unequip him like normal. Hmm...
[Jumped at the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpedAtTheCall): Ramuh told him via psychic dreams to prepare to join your party someday soon. Mog's response? "Cool!"
[Killer Rabbit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillerRabbit): In the World of Balance, Mog's Dances are wicked strong. In the World of Ruin, Mog makes for a great Dragoon.
[Last of His Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHisKind): Unfortunately it appears the rest of Mog's tribe did not survive the year under Kefka's rule.
[Magic Dance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicDance): Learned through fighting in the relevant environments.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): El Niño is a water-elemental attack.

[Nature Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NatureHero): In a fashion, as several of his dances bring forth various animals to either attack enemies or heal/buff the party, not to mention his friendship with Umaro.
[Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember): He never needs to join up with the Returners once his tribe is done helping Locke protect Terra.

[Permanently Missable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent): The Water Harmony Dance can only be learned in the World of Balance via the Serpent Trench or the Lethe River in the original game. The GBA version adds one last chance to get it if you acquire him in the World of Ruin and take him into the optional boss battle with Leviathan, but if you don't, it's gone for good.
[Petal Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetalPower): His Rage Dance attack sends a wave of slicing leaves at enemies.
[Pintsized Powerhouse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PintsizedPowerhouse): He's under five feet but a very useful party member.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): His Will o' the Wisp summons spectral fire to damage enemies.
[The Power of Rock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfRock): He uses the power of Dance to harness the forces of earth (basically Geomancy).

[Rapid-Fire Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapidFireFisticuffs): His Desperation Maneuver is "Moogle Rush", which looks and acts like Sabin's Pummel/Zanretsuken blitz (just without the flare-up around him on start-up).
[Ridiculously Cute Critter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyCuteCritter): He's a *Moogle*. It comes with the territory as a two-foot tall, fluffy white creature with tiny pink wings.
