[Series Mascot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriesMascot): Mog regularly pops up to give you tutorials on gameplay and at one point is the character you control to pick which of three scenarios to play through, and in North America he got to be on the game's boxart and in its television commercials. His prominence died down later though, as the rest of the game's cast got more recognition and re-releases of it give no particular prominence to Mog in marketing.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): His Plasma attack deals lightning-elemental damage, and takes the form of pillars of energy rising over enemies.

[Stone Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoneWall): He's not very fast, and his damage output is outpaced by several other characters. That said, he has the game's best natural Defense stat. With the right equipment, he can even hit the [Cap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cap) for defense.
[Tagalong Kid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongKid): Assuming Moogles have roughly the same lifespan as humans. He's only twelve years old.
[Uplifted Animal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpliftedAnimal): Learned to speak the human language through a series of psychic dreams with Ramuh.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): Mog (and all other Moogles) end their sentences with "kupo", kupo!

[You Can Talk?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCanTalk): The Party's reaction when he is formally introduced, as the other Moogles in *[Final Fantasy VI](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVI)*, as well as all previous games, just say "kupo". Mog claims Ramuh taught him to speak through psychic dreams.
[Attack! Attack! Attack!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack): His method of fighting is to just keep attacking.

[Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical): Umaro is bar none the strongest physical fighter in the game, but his uncontrollable nature renders him incompatible with even the most basic of strategies. [Unless said strategy equates to "let Umaro run wild"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CursedWithAwesome).

[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): You can't control him at all. The most you can do is equip him with relics that alter his attack patterns. His permanent Berserker status comes in handy in the Fanatics' Tower, since melee attacks are otherwise locked-out there.
[Bigfoot, Sasquatch, and Yeti](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigfootSasquatchAndYeti): Explicitly referred to as the latter two.

[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): He's a purely physical fighter who can't be controlled in battle, but equipping a certain accessory can add other moves to his arsenal, such as frost breath.

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): You can sometimes see him peering out from a cavern in Narshe in the World of Balance, but you won't be able to reach or interact with him until the World of Ruin.

[Cursed with Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CursedWithAwesome): Sometimes Umaro's uncontrollable nature is a blessing in disguise. He completely ignores the restrictions on attacking in the Cultists' Tower, he can still attack while Cyan is charging his Bushidos, and he'll never do anything stupid in the Coliseum. (The only other character for whom this last can apply is Gogo, depending on how you set up his/her abilities).
[Defeat Means Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansPlayable): You have to fight him as a boss before he'll join the party.

[Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle): Umaro's muscles are as thick and hard as the mountain stone. So is his head. Mog lampshades this trope as the reason to bring him along: without Mog around to give him commands, Umaro would be helpless.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): You can occasionally catch him peeking out from a then-unreachable cave in the World of Balance. (It's only after defeating Valigarmanda in the World of Ruin that this cave opens up).

[Fastball Special](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FastballSpecial): When Umaro has the Berserker Ring equipped, he'll randomly throw party members at enemies for increased damage. Sometimes he'll "throw" himself, which is interpreted as a lunging body crash more than anything.
    - If he uses a sleeping or confused party member as a projectile, they snap back to normal! Best of all, those characters get priority when Umaro moves to toss someone.
[Hulk Speak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HulkSpeak): He only has a couple lines of dialogue, but he speaks worse than Gau!

[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): If Umaro has the Blizzard Orb equipped, he will sometimes attack enemies with an ice storm. Also, due to being permanently equipped with the Snow Muffler, he'll absorb ice-elemental spells to restore HP.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): The battle with him in the SNES version uses his name. The Japanese text and all later translations just call him "Yeti" until the actual naming screen.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): He's one of the physically strongest characters in the entire series, has a high HP total and can equip the [Snow Muffler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorOfInvincibility) (the best armor in the game), and he's surprisingly fast to boot.

[Not Completely Useless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotCompletelyUseless): His limited skillset makes him a surprisingly good choice for the Coliseum, where all characters become uncontrollable and can use any of their abilities at random. As Umaro can't use items or learn any magic, he'll always use the same handful of attacking abilities, ensuring he doesn't do anything stupid like cast a spell the enemy is immune to or waste a valuable item. He's completely also unaffected by the Fanatics' Tower's restrictions on attacking.

[Primitive Clubs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrimitiveClubs): Umaro's favorite weapon is a huge club carved from [bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadWithTheBone), reflecting his nature as an unintelligent, fairly brutish yeti.
[Secret Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretCharacter): Hidden away deep in the mines of Narshe, recruiting him is optional. However, Mog gives a hint how to meet him.

[Turns Red](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed): In the boss fight with him, after he takes enough damage, Umaro buffs himself with a Green Cherry (an item that, for the player, cures Imp). [This effect doesn't happen for him as a player character, sadly.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation)
[Unskilled, but Strong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnskilledButStrong): Umaro cannot learn magic, equip Espers, or change equipment. What he can do is batter enemies into a pulp with his club.

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) is that Umaro is four years old. Though it was actually four years since Mog had him start counting, so this is likely not accurate.

[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): The character quote in the GBA version extends it to ambiguous *species.* Hidden price modifiers in the game and his Japanese honorifics imply they're a man, but who really knows?

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Gets one out of *sheer mimicry*.
QUOTE **Gogo:** I have been idle for too long. Perhaps I should mimic you... Tell me, what are you doing here? [...] You say you are going to save the world? Then I guess that means I shall save the world as well!

[Continuity Nod](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityNod): To *[Final Fantasy V](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV)* boss Gogo and to the Mimic class in general. A common fan theory is that they're the same person, since Gogo works the same way as Mimes did in *V*. Presumably when Gogo cast themself into the Void in *V*, they wound up in the world of *VI*.
[Epic Flail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EpicFlail): Their [Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword) in the ports is the Scorpion Tail flail.
[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): Their personality isn't elaborated too much.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Gogo and fellow secret character Umaro are polar opposites. Gogo can do everything but not well due to their terrible stats; Umaro does one thing and does it very well thanks to his fantastic physical stats.
[Fragile Speedster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FragileSpeedster): Gogo's Speed stat is the only one that doesn't absolutely suck, and they really can't take many hits either.

[Master of None](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfNone): Gogo can learn just about every skill that's normally accessible to your characters, and has all-around balanced stats. However, those stats are only balanced on a relative scale; As a party member, Gogo has the worst stats by far, and they can't raise them much higher because they can't equip Espers. So they can do anything, but nothing well.
[Nerf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Nerf): Just like Gau.
[Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember): Recruiting Gogo isn't necessary to complete the game.

[Power Copying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerCopying): A variant in that Gogo typically steals the abilities of the other heroes, rather than Gogo's enemies. Anything the other Returners can do, Gogo can do too... just not as well because of Gogo's terrible stats. Gogo also specifically imitates what the other *active* party members can do — if equipping magic from the menu, Gogo can only cast a spell learned by someone else currently in the party. Gogo also has the special ability Mimic, which allows them to repeat the last action one of your party members did, even if the corresponding command isn't set.

[Powers as Programs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowersAsPrograms): Gogo can equip almost any other character's special ability (except Terra's Trance, Shadow's Throw if he died and [Desperation Attacks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack)), and does need to equip appropriately to use some of them, though. This includes equipping appropriate relics to use altered abilities, like Mug or Gil Toss.
[Secret Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretCharacter): Recruiting Gogo requires you to engage in battle with a giant sandworm that swallows the party whole. Gogo lives in its innards.
[Weak, but Skilled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakButSkilled): They have very poor stats but an unmatched level of versatility in their abilities.
[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony): They ruthlessly shoot their way through Narshe, killing numerous citizens, but are promptly eradicated when Tritoch stirs.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Biggs is called Vicks in the Super Nintendo version (as well as Virtual Console and Classic Edition). Contrary to popular belief, this is not due to a mistake by Woolsey, but a simple transliteration error in the original Japanese (as Biggs would be ビッグス and not ビックス). Regardless, every other English re-release changes his name to Biggs to keep the intended reference, but every Japanese re-release keeps the spelling the same despite changing it in other Square games; for example, when the names were reused for minor characters in *[Chrono Trigger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/ChronoTrigger)*, the Japanese text corrected it to ビッグス over ビックス but the English text still kept it as Vicks until the DS port.

[Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mooks): Outside of their robot suits, they're just ordinary soldiers, unlike Terra who has a wider array of Magitek attacks. They don't even get unique sprites or portraits, and are practically interchangeable with each other. They're just there so Terra doesn't have to fight the introductory battles alone.
[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): They're named after two Rebel pilots from *[Star Wars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars)*.
[Those Two Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseTwoGuys): Even less relevant than usual, given their very brief appearance, but they do talk a little about the war and magic.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): They're killed off after less than ten minutes of gameplay.
[Badass Preacher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassPreacher): His class in the GBA version is "Oracle", and he heals the party by praying.
[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): Leader of the Returners and thus the commander of those resisting the Empire's control.

[Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty): Upon meeting Terra, one of the first things he brings up is how she killed fifty soldiers in three minutes. When Edgar and Locke chide him for distressing Terra and not taking her amnesia into account, Banon says that there's no point in her hiding from the truth. He's also entirely blunt about how badly the Returners need her abilities, though he leaves the door open for her to refuse his request.
[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): His Pray ability basically casts Cura on the party for no MP cost, and he can still help out offensively well enough.

[Escort Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EscortMission): Oddly, one of the few easy ones (since you can control him, leaving no room for [Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins) behavior).
[Good Is Not Nice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotNice): He is a stern but insightful leader.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Early in the game, he accompanies the party on the escape from the hideout.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Officially Banon, but some translations give him "Bannon" instead. It's also been translated as "Vernon" and, even less impressively, "Banan" by some fan translators.
[La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance): The guy in charge of the Returners that fight to save the world from the Empire.
[Manly Facial Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManlyFacialHair): He sports a truly enormous beard that gives him an impressive and imposing appearance.
[The Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMedic): His special ability is to heal everyone for free.

[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): He mostly delegates responsibilities to Edgar and Locke, and must be protected from harm in battle. He's purely a support character who can heal everyone for 0 MP.

[Non-Standard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardGameOver): If he gets KO'ed even once (most likely against Ultros), it's an automatic game over. He can't be used at all during the second siege on Narshe, and if any enemy reaches him, you lose by default since he's the one standing between Kefka and the Esper.

[Sadly Mythtaken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadlyMythtaken): He relates to Terra a story that is based on Pandora's Box, and the evils unleashed from it when it was opened were the [Seven Deadly Sins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SevenDeadlySins) (minus Lust and Gluttony). Aside from combining Greek and Christian mythos, the stories of Pandora's Box never specified its contents beyond evils both emotional and physical (like disease and illness). <sup>note </sup>  The Greeks *did* have a "proto-version" of the Seven Deadly Sins, the Eight Evil Thoughts, but Envy wasn't one of them and they still had nothing to do with Pandora's Box

[Supporting Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingLeader): He's the leader of the Returners and thus the driving force in the war on the Empire, but aside from the trip with him to Narshe, he's working in the background while the player pursues various leads on how to gain an edge in the struggle.

tropeName: We Cannot Go On Without You
tropeNotes: [We Cannot Go On Without You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCannotGoOnWithoutYou): If Banon falls in battle, it's a [Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameOver). Very irritating for many players who probably shouted "Why can't I use a Phoenix Down on him!?"

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): The party lose track of him in the World of Ruin, and it's probable that the Returners perished along with the Empire. Word of God states you're supposed to use your imagination.
[Wild Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildHair): His face is lost in a fiery mane of hair and beard.
[You ALL Look Familiar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouALLLookFamiliar): He uses the same sprite as Duncan in the World of Ruin, albeit slightly recolored. This will undoubtedly startle most players.
[Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): The Super NES release referred to the Ghost as an "it", but the Advance port uses male terminology.
[Bedsheet Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BedsheetGhost): He has the general appearance of this, as do the other ghost characters that aren't so friendly.

[Crouching Moron, Hidden Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrouchingMoronHiddenBadass): No equipment and an ability [Too Awesome to Use](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooAwesomeToUse), but when you do use it (preferably against a strong miniboss on the train), it performs a [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) to instantly kill the target.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): In his sprite, his portrait has a face, but not a very human one.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Only appears in the short Phantom Train sequence.
[In the Hood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheHood): Wears a white hood which leaves its face in shadow.

[Loophole Abuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoopholeAbuse): Since you can only use the Ghost during a time when you don't fight any bosses, they didn't bother giving the bosses in the main game resistance to Possess, so even enemies immune to instant death will perish. This can only be accomplished with glitches or hacking, though.
[My Name Is ???](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyNameIsQuestionMarks): Since it's a Ghost that never talks, the party has no idea what to call it, and neither does the interface.
[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): Possess kills any enemy instantly.

[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): As can be expected, being a ghost. <sup>note </sup>  This is accomplished by any ghosts being permanently equipped with Lich Rings, which explains why healing them outside of battle works.
[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): Possess kills the Ghost and removes him from the party.
[Accomplice by Inaction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AccompliceByInaction): Believes this about himself for not speaking out when Terra was enslaved by the Empire.

[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): His artwork and portrait depict him with dark skin, but his field sprite is peach. This is due to limitations of the game's color palettes though, since character sprites share palettes and there just isn't enough room on Leo's to allow him a unique skin tone. The smartphone version darkened his sprite's skin (though still not to the extent of his portrait and art) and most spin-offs tend to depict him with darker skin, though not always. An [IPS patch for the SNES version](https://www.romhacking.net/hacks/5154/) restores his skintone closer to his artwork.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Wears an awesome green military coat.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): He refused a Magitek infusion and thus has no magical powers at all. In the five minutes you control him, he proves that he doesn't *need* them; with top-tier equipment, amazing stats, and a powerful ability, he is far more powerful than the rest of the party.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): Spin-off titles often treat Leo like a core member of the *Final Fantasy VI* playable cast, and he tends to appear more often and with greater prominence than some of the actual permanent party members.
[Cultured Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedWarrior): His Ultimania profile lists his hobby as "appreciating music" and his favorite thing being "chivalry".
[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): Just before he dies, he has finally had enough with Kefka and tries to fight back.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): Leo battles Kefka one-on-one.
[Due to the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DueToTheDead): Gets a burial mound and funeral scene, sponsored by the people who should have been his enemies but had respect for his kind and noble nature.

[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): After the party forms an uneasy alliance with Gestahl, Leo serves as adjunct to the Emperor and journeys with them to Thamasa to find the Esper refugees.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): He tells his soldiers not to be too eager to rush into battle and think of their families waiting for them to come home.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Kefka. Leo is a rational, principled general who treats everyone with respect, even the enemies of the Empire. Kefka is a [laughing mad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaughingMad) psychopath who treats his soldiers like [disposable peons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves). Leo is well-respected by imperial troops, while Kefka is universally hated by the troops.
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): You only control him once in the game, for a very short time. That's all he needs to prove you that his General rank isn't for show.
[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): He refused to undergo esper infusion, but his Shock ability still deals *magic* damage.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): The brief scene in Thamasa where he's the only party member is the one and only time he's playable.

[Hero Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist): Sabin describes him as "the guy with the principles", also saying "he could be my friend if he weren't my enemy" when encountering him in an Imperial Camp.

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice): His morals put him in conflict with the more underhanded Kefka, who loses patience with Leo and brutally stabs him to death.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): Leo is killed by Kefka in Thamasa, and there's no way to bring him back to life.

[Master of All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfAll): His base stats are ridiculous — his Strength, Stamina and defenses are comparable to Umaro, and his Speed and Evasion are comparable to Shadow. In other words, Leo is just as strong and hardy as a sasquatch and as fast as a ninja assassin. His Magic stat is his worst stat only on a comparative level, he's on-par with Celes and Strago and just behind Terra and Relm.

[Military Mage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryMage): General Leo also acts primarily as an officer, leading the siege of Doma Castle but never taking the field himself that we can see. He's more than capable, however, having a unique multi-target magical Shock attack not equaled by the party until the endgame. Unfortunately, the only time we see him use it is when he's fighting Kefka after the latter gets a massive [Next Tier Powerup](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NextTierPowerup), and Leo comes down with a fatal case of [The Worf Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfEffect).
[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): He's a great guy, but his [Evil Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilEmpire) comes first.

[Nice to the Waiter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceToTheWaiter): How do we know from his first appearance that General Leo is an [Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain)? He tells an Imperial he's not going to attack Doma again because it'll cause too many casualties on both sides, and doesn't want his men throwing their lives away. That, and he actually speaks to Kefka like a person, as opposed to the heroes and other Imperials who speak about him like the [Monster Clown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterClown) he really is.

[Nominal Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NominalVillain): The only reason Leo's an enemy of the Returners is because he works for the Empire. Even then, Leo attempts to minimize casualties on both sides, is [A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen), and has a sense of honor and morality. As Sabin notes, "he could be my friend if he weren't my enemy." The few times he works with the party, he's also very polite and courteous, even giving Terra some genuine words of encouragement. When he pulls a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) against Kefka, it's not much of a shock; Leo didn't have very far to turn.

["Not So Different" Remark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoDifferentRemark): Brought up by Leo himself. Leo admitted that he felt ashamed over doing nothing when Kefka enslaved Terra using the Slave Crown, and that his passivity made him no better than Kefka.

[Officer and a Gentleman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OfficerAndAGentleman): He's one of the Empire's best warriors, and he's also polite, noble, values the lives of friend and foe alike, and is disgusted by Kefka's wanton bloodthirst.

[Purposely Overpowered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurposelyOverpowered): When you use him as a party member, he has a powerful sword, a shield that can block magic attacks, a relic to attack four times a turn, and a good deal more HP than your party members unless you do a lot of level grinding. It's to ensure you win the obligatory storyline battle he's used for.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath): He finally turns against Kefka when he witnesses Kefka's genocide of the Espers, but it's too late, and he's killed as a traitor.

[Sacrificial Lion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLion): Kefka killing him, his own ally and one of the Empire's best officers, is a sign that any lingering lines Kefka might not have crossed yet have now been crossed.
[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): Of the [Evil Empire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilEmpire), he's the only one with a sense of morals (after Celes defects).

[Universally Beloved Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniversallyBelovedLeader): His subordinates have nothing but gushing things to say about him, and even his *enemies* hold him in high regard. Even Cyan, whose country had been besieged by Leo's army for the previous three years, expressed dismay at news of his demise. Kefka seems to be the only person in the entire world who hates him.
[Weapon Tombstone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaponTombstone): His sword is stuck into his grave.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): He is the consummate worthy opponent — as the characters say, "He could be my friend, if he weren't my enemy..."
    - He also seems to view the Returners in a similar way, as can be witnessed in his appearance in the Imperial Camp near Doma Castle.
[You're Insane!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoureInsane): His last words in the GBA translation are to shout this to Kefka before he's killed.
[The Caretaker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaretaker): He implies he helped raise Celes as a child and has been watching over her during her military career.

[Defector from Decadence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefectorFromDecadence): At the banquet, he counts himself as a Returner, because the Empire has just gone too far for him to take after he learned about Magicite.
[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): This game's Cid.

[Plotline Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotlineDeath): If Celes doesn't feed him fast-swimming fish, or just takes too long to feed him at all. *[Dissidia Final Fantasy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/DissidiaFinalFantasy)* implies that his death is canon, while *[Final Fantasy Record Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyRecordKeeper)*, a mobile game retelling the stories of the various games, states the contrary.
[Promotion to Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotionToParent): On Solitary Island, Celes says that Cid is her "granddad" and she his granddaughter.

[Reluctant Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantMadScientist): Kind of. He says he was threatened by Kefka, but he was extracting power from Espers long before (his process is what *created* Kefka). He does express remorse when confronted with people who point out how awful his actions are.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Cid developed the Magitek Knight project, but the first of the Knights went insane while still getting great power. The test subject's name? Kefka.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Possibly because his original name "Jun" was [oddly Japanese](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AerithAndBob).
[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): He helpfully talks with Terra and then Locke at the beginning of the game, helping to set up the Returners' conflict with the Empire.

[Unfazed Everyman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnfazedEveryman): Arvis is the Returner to go to in Narshe, and tags along with Banon when the Returners travel to Vector for peace negotiations with the Empire. Arvis is resourceful, but he isn't a combatant.
[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): This trope applies to Arvis in exactly the same way it applies to Banon. See Banon's entry.
[Badass Armfold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmfold): Takes it to an art form, striking this pose almost every other animation.

[Faking the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FakingTheDead): Though it's unknown why he never appears in person until the World of Ruin, or how he survived his encounter with Vargas when everyone (including Vargas) thought he didn't.

[Guide Dang It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt): In the World of Ruin, his home is in a completely different location relative to the rest of the world than it was in the World of Balance. Talking to his wife does provide an oblique hint to its location, but finding it can still be tricky considering that it's not marked on the map in the normal way, appearing as a formation of trees.
[The Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMentor): To Sabin and Vargas, teaching them all he knows about martial arts.
[Mentor Occupational Hazard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorOccupationalHazard): Killed by his own son, or at least believed to be.
[Old Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldMaster): He's old, but he's still a powerful martial artist. Teaches martial arts to itinerant princes.
[Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap): He's got Banon sprites, just with darker coloring.

[Cool Airship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolAirship): It might not have a casino on it, but it's pretty cool nonetheless. Cid did note the Blackjack would be a lot faster without the casino weighing it down. No wonder the Falcon could always beat it in a race.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Has shades, laughing and jokingly ribbing how Setzer can't compare to her.
[Gender-Blender Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenderBlenderName): Darill is usually a man's name.
[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Daril, Daryl, Darril, Darryl?
[Lady of Adventure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfAdventure): She sure had no problem with taking risks and living her life to the fullest, a philosophy Setzer adopted.

[Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest): Though not outright stated, the flashback scenes of her and Setzer have undeniable [romantic undertones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease). He even tells her he'll wait on "[their] hill" for her to come back.
[Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter): Died in a race with Setzer.
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): To Setzer, as his [Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest) and fellow airship pilot.
[Arm Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmCannon): If you look closely at his left hand, you can see he has a gun mounted on his arm. It's represented by his armor-piercing ability Hyperdrive.
[The Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheArtifact): The subplot with the impostor Siegfried? Possibly intended as part of the subquest to fight Gogo before he was moved, but that detail was left in.
[Badass Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCape): He wears a large dark blue cape.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): Who is this guy? What does he want? Is he a friend or an enemy? How does he know Ultros? It doesn't help that apparently there's an impostor Siegfried running around, so each time you encounter him, who knows if it's the real thing or not.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): Is it Siegfried or Ziegfried? In the Super NES version this is a plot point: the weak goofball you effortlessly spank on the Phantom Train is Ziegfried (or sometimes Sigfried), who is impersonating Siegfried, the legendary swordsman who hands you your ass on a platter at the Coliseum. Later releases removed the distinction and they're both "Siegfried".
[The Rival](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival): To Ultros, apparently. Ultros tries to steal the statues in the Esper Caves to get his attention.

[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): Bet a Megalixir in the Coliseum to face him in a proper fight. He's moderately strong on his own, but the [Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss) nature of the Coliseum combined with the fact you can't control your character bumps him up to end-game difficulty, usually requiring a [One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) build to beat him before he does the same.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): In the World of Ruin, you find him trailing Gerad and the thieves into Figaro Castle. Once you get through the cave, though, he vanishes, and it's never revealed what he was doing there.

[Zero-Effort Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZeroEffortBoss): The fight against him on the Phantom Train is a complete joke. If you're using the Black Belt accessory, he will probably die during his (really weak) initial attack flurry; even if he doesn't, he'll die in one hit to nearly anything. But it's later indicated that the one on the Phantom Train is the impostor.
[Beast and Beauty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeastAndBeauty): Maduin is the Esper Beast to Madeline's human Beauty.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): In the original SNES release, Madeline's name was given as Madonna, as a deliberate reference to her status as [the mother of Terra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadonnaArchetype), a [Messianic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MessianicArchetype). Additionally, the Esper's name is usually translated as Maduin in *FFVI* translations, but the same name has been translated as Madeen (e.g. in *[Final Fantasy IX](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIX)*).

[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): Maduin's Magicite teaches Fira, Blizzara and Thundara. Maduin's summon attack, however, is [Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental).
[G-Rated Sex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GRatedSex): How they conceive Terra — they fly around the screen in trails of sparkles, and the sparkles come together to form baby Terra.

[Interspecies Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterspeciesRomance): Maduin was an Esper, Madeline was a human; Their love was a testament that the two races *could* co-exist peacefully, even if on a small scale.

[Jack of All Trades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JackOfAllTrades): While the menu is not enabled during the flashback when the player controls Maduin, hacking the game reveals that nearly all of his stats are 30.

[Madonna Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadonnaArchetype): Madeline is depicted as something of a "virgin" mother (via [G-Rated Sex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GRatedSex)) whose daughter with the Esper Maduin is Terra, a [Half-Human Hybrid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfHumanHybrid) who can bridge the two worlds.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): In keeping with Terra being a [Messianic Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MessianicArchetype), in the Super NES translation Madeline was called "[Madonna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadonnaArchetype)", as in the virgin mother.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): They only appear in a small handful of scenes, but as they are Terra's parents, Maduin's romance with Madonna may just be the catalyst for the game's entire plot.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Madeline suddenly getting ejected from the Esper Realm in the wake of the Empire's invasion left her disoriented and dying, and in her desperation, she gave the infant Terra to the nearest person she could find. Unfortunately, she realized too late that this person was Emperor Gestahl himself. He didn't give poor Madeline the chance to correct her mistake. Terra's nature as a [Half-Human Hybrid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfHumanHybrid) would become a breakthrough in Magitek research, allowing Gestahl to begin his world-conquering campaign.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Kefka betrays him and gets the power of The Warring Triad and uses it to knock Gestahl off a cliff, killing him. Considering that this only happened to him because he [betrayed Kefka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToScapegoat), and taking into account his other crimes as an [Evil Overlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOverlord), it's easy to say he had it coming.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Gestahl, after demonstrating a willingness to dispose of anyone who has outlived their usefulness (including Leo and Shadow), turns on Kefka after the clown tries to meddle with the Triad.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): In the World of Balance, though Kefka is established as the [Dragon-in-Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonInChief) in that portion.
[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): He tries to take the power of the Warring Triad for himself but Kefka betrays him and kicks him to his death.
[Bodyguard Betrayal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyguardBetrayal): Gestahl appears with Kefka thoroughly on his side on the Floating Continent. And then Kefka must show them the meaning of power...

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): One of the first bosses to invoke this trope, but the technology of the time (cartridge) made it less obvious. Still, when the player is confronting Gestahl, one can't help but think the game is a little short.

[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath): Kefka has enough of taking orders and usurps Gestahl at the height of his power by kicking him off the Floating Continent to his demise.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): From "Gastra" or "Ghastla" in Japanese.
[The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor): His title and position as the ruler of the Gestahlian Empire.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): He desired to rule the world, but when Kefka decided to demand that the Warring Triad expose their true power, he attempts to stop Kefka, [feeling that it was going too far](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVersusOblivion). In addition, when Kefka murders General Leo, he claims that he'll simply report that he disposed of a traitor as an excuse for murdering him, implying that Gestahl would not have approved of Kefka killing General Leo, even though he manipulated the latter, unless there was good reason. He was also against the decimation of Doma.

[Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy): He assumes he has a tight leash on Kefka the whole time when in reality, the mad jester is much, *much* stronger than his Emperor and has very little loyalty to the man.
[Evil Old Folks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOldFolks): He's in his 60s and is the main antagonist. Flashbacks imply he's been at work building the Empire and conquering the world for over 20 years.

[Evil Overlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOverlord): Ruler of the Gestahlian Empire from the capital of Vector, spends much of the game never being seen, wants to [Take Over the World](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeOverTheWorld)...

[Falsely Reformed Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalselyReformedVillain): When the Espers annihilate the capital city of Vector he feigns repentance and vows to end the war, even imprisoning Kefka for war crimes (that he committed without Gestahl's approval, supposedly) and hosting a dinner for the heroes before they go on their mission to save the world. [He lays it on so thick that nobody believes him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExaggeratedTrope), but the party reluctantly attends for lack of alternatives. To the surprise of nobody, it's all a scheme to corner the heroes so Gestahl can get his hands on the Warring Triad.

[Godzilla Threshold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodzillaThreshold): Eventually tries to use Meltdown on Kefka. Keep in mind Meltdown is one of the most powerful spells in the game and hits the enemy *and* caster parties for heavy damage. Gestahl was clearly desperate.
[Hoist by His Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard): Gestahl meets his doom at the hands of his genetically altered [Super-Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperSoldier).

[I Surrender, Suckers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ISurrenderSuckers): When the Espers torch his city as punishment for using their kind for experiments, Gestahl waves the white flag and enlists his longtime enemies, the Returners, to broker peace with the Espers. He shows his true colors when Kefka kills everyone at the summit, then escapes back into the Esper realm with the Emperor.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): It's very fitting that Emperor Gestahl dies at the hands of Kefka after he was responsible for having Kefka infused with magical powers, and had him [Promoted to Scapegoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToScapegoat) when things started going wrong. Add additional karmic points for the fact that Kefka kills him using the power of the Warring Triad, the very things he has pursued all of this time.

[Military Brat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryBrat): According to the *Final Fantasy VI* timeline, Gestahl was from a well-off military family. It's also strongly implied that his father was heavily involved in a large coup that resulted in Vector becoming an Empire.

tropeName: A Nazi by Any Other Name
tropeNotes: [A Nazi by Any Other Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ANaziByAnyOtherName): Let's see... He's an amazingly charismatic dictator with a German-sounding name attempting to conquer the world, his troops are obliquely compared to Nazi stormtroopers in a reference to a scene from *[Star Wars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars)*, his troops use the "Nazi arm-raise salute", he keeps Espers in a Magitek Research Facility <sup>note </sup>  concentration camp , and... oh, he wanted to create a "master race" by breeding Celes and Kefka. His characterization is also quite similar to Mussolini and his Fascism movement, especially when taking into account the fact that he was essentially trying to resurrect an old empire of Magic.

tropeName: No, Mr. Bond, I Expect You to Dine
tropeNotes: [No, Mr. Bond, I Expect You to Dine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoMrBondIExpectYouToDine): After the Espers razed Vector, Gestahl seemingly has a change of heart (or at least realizes that after the Esper attack he has no chance against the Returners), asks for the ceasefire, invites the party to the dinner party, blames everything on Kefka, asks the party to find the Espers and negotiate with them to prevent another War of the Magi. The party doesn't fall for it, but they play along since they really need to convince the Espers not to destroy everything. And they leave behind lots of people to uncover the plans.
[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil): Wears black and red robes, is an old man, and styles himself [The Emperor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEmperor).
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Uses Firaga, Flare and Meltdown when he attacks Kefka on the Floating Continent.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): In the SNES version, at least, Emperor Gestahl tries to stop Kefka from doing something that will cause [The End of the World as We Know It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEndOfTheWorldAsWeKnowIt), because he wants to rule the world, not blow it up. Kefka kills him. In the GBA version, his final words were "The world will now experience true fear..." before being kicked off by Kefka, implying that it was closer to [Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards).

tropeName: Red and Black and Evil All Over
tropeNotes: [Red and Black and Evil All Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedAndBlackAndEvilAllOver): His robes are red and black, and he's the only character in the game with that color scheme.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath): In a sense. He realized just how dangerous Kefka was and tried to stop him from ending the world, and got killed for his efforts. With that being said, it was more likely just a case of [Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy).

[Shipper on Deck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipperOnDeck): In the [GBA](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/GameBoyAdvance) [version](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpdatedRerelease), on the Floating Continent Gestahl invites Celes to create a new generation of Magitek children for the Gestahlian Empire with Kefka.

[Shoot the Dangerous Minion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDangerousMinion): Attempted by Emperor Gestahl. Let's just say that trying to kill Kefka on a Floating Continent miles above the surface is a BAD idea, especially when Kefka is wielding the power of three gods combined.
[This Cannot Be!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisCannotBe): His reaction to Kefka surviving the best spells Gestahl can throw at him.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): Even when it becomes abundantly clear that Kefka is a psychopath, Gestahl keeps Kefka in his inner circle. Gestahl pays dearly for his poor judgment atop the Floating Continent.
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Kefka zaps him before you get the chance.

[Unwitting Instigator of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingInstigatorOfDoom): Seizing the Floating Continent to take the power of the Warring Triad works out extremely well, and the heroes [are unable to stop them.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreTooLate) Too bad Kefka is more than a bit [Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy), and Gestahl was a [Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter) for him and had no one else to fall back onto for this plan; he ends up an [Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn) to the mad clown's spur of the moment decision to disrupt the Triad's formation due to [Celes stabbing him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero), along with the sight of his own blood and then gets murdered right before Kefka [ends the world.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins)
[We Can Rule Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCanRuleTogether): Atop the Floating Continent, he offers Celes the chance to join him and Kefka to rule the world.

[While Rome Burns](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhileRomeBurns): Orders a banquet and dines with the Returners mere hours after Vector was attacked by the Espers. The buildings are still burning when you leave afterwards.
[The Worf Barrage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfBarrage): His magic barrage against Kefka serves to show just how powerful Kefka has become.

[Xanatos Speed Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/XanatosSpeedChess): He plays a mean game of it; everything the Returners do advances his goals in ways even he didn't necessarily anticipate. When Kefka betrayed him, Gestahl not only had a lot of Magicite in his possession, but he also controlled the source of all magic in the world, and he did it by rolling with his defeats and finding ways to further his plans in spite of them.

[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): Though he was purged along with his platoon, he did manage to capture an Esper and his half-human daughter (after killing her mother in cold blood) for research.

[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): Possibly. If the Ultimania artbook is to be believed, Gestahl is only 50 years old. Other sources, however, give the far more believable claim that he is in his 70s.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Concept art shows that Tetsuya Nomura did give them names but they aren't used in the final product. They are used in *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*.

[Bowdlerise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bowdlerise): The Goddess was give more clothing in the American SNES version, as well as every post-2000 re-release in all regions (though not as much as US SNES ver.). The names of the other two may have also been subjected to some, but it's debatable - see "Inconsistent Spelling", below.

[Color-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedForYourConvenience): Demon is red, Fiend is primarily black/blue with gold wings, and Goddess wears blue and bears a gold crest. *Dissidia* assigns them colors in a roundabout way — the three circles that appear during Kefka's [EX Burst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) are in the same formation as the Triad, and Demon's is red, Fiend's is yellow, and Goddess's is blue.

[Cosmic Keystone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicKeystone): Their existence is key to the continued existence of magic. In the backstory, magic first entered the world when they descended from the heavens to do war with each other. They took some humans and turned them into espers to use as soldiers in their armies. The alignment they left themselves in when they became statues was essential to preventing their magic from being unleashed upon the world. Move them out of alignment and the imbalance of power drastically reshapes the known world, which is exactly what Kefka does once he sends Gestahl flying. Kefka drains their power and ends up becoming this, and the Triad's destruction near the end of the game thus does not result in the cessation of magic.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Fiend is by far the most grotesque of the three.

[Fire, Ice, Lightning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireIceLightning): They each correspond to one of the three basic elements in the game's magic system. Demon is Fire, Fiend is Ice, and Goddess is Lightning.
[Female Angel, Male Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemaleAngelMaleDemon): The two male gods are obviously demonic while the female is angelic.

[God Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodIsEvil): Though their backstory reveals they realized the havoc they were causing and stopped. By the time you meet them at the end of the game, they're fighting for Kefka for whatever reason. Hell, thanks to Kefka absorbing most of their energies, they barely even qualify as gods by that point.
[Good Wings, Evil Wings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodWingsEvilWings): Demon has angel wings, Fiend has demon wings.

[Inconsistent Spelling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InconsistentSpelling): With a possible side of [Bowdlerizing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bowdlerize). While "Goddess" (*megami*, めがみ) has never really been in contention, an entire *generation* of fans and translators have struggled to come up with good translations for the other two, who are *majin* (魔神) for the blue muscly one and *kishin* (鬼神) for the red snake one. Neither term *really* has an absolute equivalent in English, and [''kishin'' in particular describes a conceptual entity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wrathful_deities) that barely even exists in most western mythology - "War God" is sort of similar, but still not quite right. They're called "Fiend" and "Demon" in the Advance and iOS versions, though a lot of people note "Demon" is still not a very good translation for *kishin*; the SNES version called them "Doom" and "Poltergeist", probably to avoid religious references (though it's been noted that "poltergeist" is actually not an awful analogy to the "ki" part of *kishin*... it just isn't divine enough to cover the *shin*).

[Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword): Demon drops the Radiant Lance, Fiend drops the Mutsunokami, and Goddess drops the Excalibur. In the original Super NES release, the former two were the strongest weapons of their kind. Excalibur was outclassed by the Ultima Weapon, Ragnarok, and Illumina, but getting the latter two meant passing up the Ragnarok Magicite that taught [Ultima](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameBreaker) (though you could still learn that from the uncursed Paladin Shield).

[MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacGuffin): They serve as this in the first part of the game, as the source of the strongest magic in the universe. While Kefka does render them husks when you see them again in his tower, they are still powerful and are mandatory boss fights that are the last line of defense prior to the [Point of No Return](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PointOfNoReturn) and Kefka himself.
[Multi-Armed and Dangerous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultiArmedAndDangerous): Fiend has six arms.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): This is the reason why they sealed themselves as statues in the first place.
[Navel-Deep Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline): Goddess' "clothing" is two strips of material over her breasts and crotch, leaving her torso between them bare.

[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): They're not given proper names, only being referred to as Fiend, Demon, and Goddess. Concept art gives them the names Sophia (Goddess), Zurvan (Demon), and Sephirot (Fiend), which were later reused for their appearance in *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*.

[Permanently Missable Content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PermanentlyMissableContent): Hope those of you aiming for [100% Completion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHundredPercentCompletion) brought Strago to fight Fiend, because he's the only enemy in the entire game who knows the Force Field Lore. Averted in the *Advance* port, where you can fight Fiend again... if you feel like dragging Strago through the [Soul Shrine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRush).

[Secret Art](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretArt): Tyrfing for Demon, Fiendish Rage and Force Field for Fiend, and Cloudy Heaven for Goddess. Quasar is *not* exclusive to Goddess, but it is likely she'll be the first enemy you see using it, since of the only other two with it, one is a normal enemy you're likely to kill before it uses it, and the other is the GBA-exclusive Gilgamesh.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): The rest of the series contains subtle references to them, such as three statues in [Kuja's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyIX) palace resembling them, and [Yunalesca](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyX) resembling Goddess in her second form. They also appear flat-out in *[Final Fantasy XIV](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIV)*.
[Snake People](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnakePeople): Demon's concept art depicts what ended up being his sprite as the torso of a long snake body.
[Stripperiffic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Stripperiffic): Goddess. She actually got censored in the SNES version with lengthened clothes.
[Taken for Granite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakenForGranite): They turned themselves to stone centuries ago.
[Two Guys and a Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoGuysAndAGirl): The male and female Demon and Fiend, and the female Goddess.

[Actually Four Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActuallyFourMooks): The reborn Ice Dragon appears as a group of four, but their sprites overlay on top of each other so you can't pick out a specific one to target.
[Anti-Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic): The reborn Gold Dragon in Dragons' Den absorbs all magic.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Kaiser Dragon's greeting to the party when the player finds him.
QUOTE **Kaiser Dragon:** [Humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunyHumans) and your insatiable greed... [Your lust for power leads always to a lust for blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumansAreBastards)... This place is a sanctuary for wayward souls... What business have you filthy creatures here? [You slaughter my brethren, and befoul their rest with the profanity of your continued existence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero)... You should not have come here. In the name of all dragonkind, I shall grant you the death you desire. I am the dealer of destruction... I am the font from which fear springs... [I am Kaiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyNameIsInigoMontoya)... [And your time is at an end](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrepareToDie).
[Barrier Change Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierChangeBoss): Kaiser Dragon shifts his attack patterns and elemental properties throughout the battle.
[Battle Amongst the Flames](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAmongstTheFlames): Kaiser Dragon recycles the "burning house" background for the battle, resulting in this.

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): For some reason, the reborn Skull Dragon has a special hatred of Terra, and will unleash his strongest attack every fourth turn if you happen to have her in your party.

[The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker): The reborn Earth Dragon eventually enters an [Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage) and starts attacking you four times every turn.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): Storm Dragon, Dragon of Wind.
[Boss Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRush): In the Soul Shrine in the *Advance* release, their eight reborn incarnations plus Kaiser Dragon are the final opponents.

[Bragging Rights Reward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraggingRightsReward): Congratulations, you defeated Kaiser Dragon and won the Diabolos Magicite! Not that you need it — even with the Soul Shrine and Omega Weapon left, the spells Diabolos teaches are pretty useless since odds are everyone knows Ultima by now, his summon isn't that great either, and his level up bonus, in terms of pure [Min-Maxing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MinMaxing), just means that if you raise your party to Level 99, they'll have a few extra points in their other stats than they would without him.

[Cast From Life Span](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromLifeSpan): The reborn Red Dragon will eventually expire once it puts all its energy into blasting you with the most powerful attacks it can, including Ultima. It's entirely invulnerable until it does, so the party can only endure its onslaught.

[Color-Coded Characters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedCharacters): Aside from the black and grey Storm Dragon and green Skull Dragon, the Eight Dragons are colored pretty much just as you'd guess given their elemental typings as listed below. And even with those two the coloring fits.
[Deceased and Diseased](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeceasedAndDiseased): The undead Skull Dragon uses status attacks and is Poison-elemental.
[Dem Bones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemBones): The name "Skull Dragon" should be a clue.
[Dinosaurs Are Dragons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DinosaursAreDragons): Gold, Earth, and Ice Dragon are palette swaps of dinosaur-type enemies.
[Dishing Out Dirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DishingOutDirt): Earth Dragon, Dragon of Earth.

[Early-Bird Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdBoss): The game encourages you to visit Mt. Zozo pretty early on. You are encouraged to [step on a switch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait) that releases the Storm Dragon, one of the stronger of the original eight. First timers usually come up against it first. The game even throws another curveball by giving the player Thunder Shield only a few screens prior - which, among any useful traits it has, **makes the wielder** ***weak to Wind***.

[Elemental Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalPowers): Each Dragon embodies one of the eight elements of the game, with Kaiser Dragon invoking [All Your Powers Combined](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllYourPowersCombined) and combining it with [Non-Elemental](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonElemental), using a variety of attacks.
[Elemental Rock-Paper-Scissors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalRockPaperScissors): They all have elemental weaknesses except for Holy Dragon.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): A certain NPC describes them, along with Humbaba and Deathgaze, as one of the ancient monsters of the world.
[Holy Hand Grenade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HolyHandGrenade): Holy Dragon, Dragon of Holy.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): Ice Dragon, the Dragon of Ice.

[Infinity +1 Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InfinityPlusOneSword): They all guard powerful weapons in the original game, though usually not the strongest of their types. Their reborn incarnations, however, *do* drop the strongest weapons.
[Making a Splash](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash): Blue Dragon, Dragon of Water.

[No Cure for Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCureForEvil): Averted with the reborn Holy Dragon, it has Auto-Regen and a 66% chance to counter any attack by casting Curaga on itself. Reborn Skull Dragon averts No **Revivals** For Evil by endlessly reviving itself unless it runs out of MP.

[Not-So-Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain): The Holy Dragon is originally the weakest of the Eight Dragons; all of his attacks can be Reflected, so equipping the party with Reflect Rings makes him totally unable to deal damage to them. The reborn Holy Dragon is one of the strongest dragons, and in particular has learned [Heartless Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HPToOne) as a *counter-attack*. Factor in that it uses Saintly Beam, which cannot be Reflected or absorbed by Runic, and the fact that there is exactly **one** equipment piece to absorb or nullify Holy attacks, and you're looking at a [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill) if you aren't careful.

[Our Dragons Are Different](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OurDragonsAreDifferent): Red and Holy Dragon are the only ones to be a [Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap) of another one of the Eight Dragons; the other six use their own sprites among the group, and thus their appearances vary wildly.
[Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap): Except for Kaiser, they're all just recolored versions of normal dragon/dinosaur enemies.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Red Dragon, Dragon of Fire.

[Power Up Letdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerUpLetdown):
    - The reborn Blue Dragon is pretty much the same as the original, just higher stats. Its "gimmick" is just that it inflicts more status ailments on itself when using Rippler as described above, but it still only does that if you use your own status buffs. - Gold Dragon when first fought will charge up for some time... To use Bolt 3/Thundaga, which was already being used halfway through the *World of Balance*. - If you brought along Celes to fight Red Dragon, she can use Runic to absorb all of its spells.

[Puzzle Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PuzzleBoss): A couple of them in the Dragons' Den:
    - Ice Dragon if pretty normal, it's just that there are 5 of them. - Red Dragon you cannot harm at all - you just have to wait until it [burns itself out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastFromHitPoints). Be sure to cast Reraise first, since it sends an Ultima followed by Flare as it dies. - Gold Dragon has permanent [Runic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic) status, and, as such, absorbs all but few specific spells such as [Flood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MakingASplash). - Skull Dragon endlessly revives itself when killed - unless you kill them by [Rasping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManaBurn) until the dragon runs out of MP. - Holy Dragon you have to both be careful when attacking, as it can randomly counter with [Heartless Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HPToOne), yet attack enough to ensure you can get through its Auto-Regen and Curaga counters.

[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): Actually [averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope) with Skull Dragon - it has the appropriate name, looks like any other zombie dragon, and is weak to Holy, but is not considered undead.

[Secret Art](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretArt): They all get one in the Dragons' Den, aside from Earth Dragon and Storm Dragon, who had theirs originally.
    - Red Dragon: Red Fang and Eraser. - Blue Dragon: Blue Fang. - Ice Dragon: Freeze. - Holy Dragon: Heavenly Wrath. - Earth Dragon: Honed Tusk. - Storm Dragon: Leaf Swirl and Wing Saber. - Skull Dragon: Apparition and Fear. - Gold Dragon: Mighty Claw. - Kaiser Dragon: Last Breath.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): Gold Dragon.
[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): Technically, all of them are optional encounters.
[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): Kaiser Dragon is similar to Shinryu from the prior game in both appearance and role.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): Their reborn incarnations in Dragons' Den are *far* higher tiers than the originals. The Holy Dragon is particularly notable — the original is entirely incompetent and a party with [Reflect Rings](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackReflector) is invincible, but the reborn version is one of the most powerful of them.
[Universal Poison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UniversalPoison): Skull Dragon, Dragon of Poison.
[Victory by Endurance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VictoryByEndurance): There's no way to defeat the reborn Red Dragon other than simply tanking all of its attacks.

[Weaksauce Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeaksauceWeakness): Their original forms can be rendered almost helpless with basic status spells. The Ice Dragon is subseptible to Silence, as is the Holy Dragon (and it has absolutely no physical attack), Dirt Dragon can be put to Sleep, Red Dragon can be Confused and Rasped to die at 0 MP (and only has 1780 MP so that'll take only a few turns), Skull Dragon can also be Rasped to death and only has a few hundred more MP, and Gold Dragon can be Berserked so it can only use physical blows. The only ones that *can't* be locked down are the Blue Dragon and Storm Dragon. However, the Blue Dragon is fought so late into the game and has such low HP for that point that he's a pushover anyway. Appropriately, the Storm Dragon, fought early on if you follow the nudges the game gives you, is generally considered the strongest dragon.
[Worf Had the Flu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorfHadTheFlu): Their Dragons Den incarnations are far stronger, suggesting they originally were somehow not fighting at full power.
[Boss Banter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBanter): He never shuts up in any of the battles.
[Braggart Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraggartBoss): Constantly boasts he's octopus royalty that's going to thrash the party.

[Breakout Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakoutCharacter): He's just this side of [Gilgamesh](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyV), having become a recurring boss in the series, but isn't as popular or widespread.
[Combat Tentacles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatTentacles): Naturally, since he's an octopus. His trademark attack is Tentacle.
[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): The final time Ultros is fought before the Floating Continent, he brings Typhon along for the battle.

[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): Originally called "Orthros" in Japanese, as he and Typhon are [both named after Greek monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming). Later *FF* games have waffled on which version of the name to use, but the general rule seems to be that a monster which **looks like** him is Orthros, while one that actually **is** the *FFVI* character (such as the *[Final Fantasy XIII-2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyXIII2)* Coliseum DLC) is Ultros. In contrast, his buddy Typhon, who was named Chupon in the SNES version, was properly named Typhon in all installments ever since, with the exception of the original PS1 version of *[Final Fantasy VII](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/FinalFantasyVII)*, where he was named Typoon. <sup>note </sup>  It got changed back to Typhon in the PC release, as well as all future releases of the game which use the PC version's script.
[Evil Duo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilDuo): With Typhon. While Ultros is a goofy and ineffectual wisecracker, Typhon is his [Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle) bodyguard.

[Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere): Every time he appears his arrival is more unexpected, nonsensical, and at odds with events surrounding him. You'd expect some sort of aquatic boss to appear on the Lethe River, but then Ultros is suddenly able to go on land and is at the Opera House to sabotage the party's plans. Then even later he's at Crescent Island plotting to steal some statues to impress Siegfried, who Ultros has never even mentioned before. Then somehow he's flying in with the Imperial Air Force on Typhon, also never mentioned or seen before but suddenly he's Ultros' accomplice. Given how silly and pathetic Ultros is, this escalating absurdity may well be intentional.
[Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang): His pal is Chupon/Typhon, a two-headed, floating, fire-breathing monstrosity which acts as his muscle.

[Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HarmlessVillain): His battles in *VI* were never all that difficult to begin with, and he was never as formidable as his more rarely-seen friend Typhon. In the World of Ruin, Ultros is forced to work indefinitely as a receptionist to pay off his crippling debts. You can see him and speak to him as often as you please, but his role as a villain has ended.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Ultros is this in spades. While he is the game's [Plucky Comic Relief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PluckyComicRelief), he's also downright mean. He attacks your party several times throughout the game for no reason other than just because. In the battle against him in Crescent Mountain, he mouths off to Relm, a little girl who just wanted to paint his picture. This causes the party to stop fighting and *berate Ultros* for making a little girl cry! He eventually caves in. Of course, Relm had [ulterior motives](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtInitiatesLife) for painting his picture, but Ultros didn't know that and still reacted badly to it.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): He's always shouting and his sprite is sporting a wacky grin.
[Laughably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaughablyEvil): Uwehehehe! Look at him! He's a receptionist!

[Lovable Sex Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableSexManiac): In the original Japanese and newer localizations past the original SNES version, he's straight up perverted towards Terra and intent on lecherous motives, a consistent character trait he's kept ever since across the series. He's also something of a [Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey) that is doomed to fail his antagonism, keeping it from being any more than just commentary.

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): You get to tangle with Ultros several times in the World of Balance, with the very last encounter with him being prior to the Floating Continent.
[Tentacled Terror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TentacledTerror): As an enemy octopus, this is to be expected. His primary attack is simply whacking the party with his tentacles.

[Timed Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimedMission): The first battle with him has him use Tentacle on different party members at fixed intervals. Take too long and he'll attack Banon because "Your ugly mug gives me the creeps." Banon can survive this if you had the foresight to put him in the back row. If you didn't? Game over.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): In the third battle with him, after a period of time he'll gain powerful elemental spells and will become much stronger, and can even pull off a [Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill) if you aren't careful.

[To Serve Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToServeMan): The SNES translation changes his lusting after Terra in the first fight against him to [a carnivorous desire to eat her, not unlike a sapient predator after prey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SapientEatSapient).
QUOTE **Ultros: (original/future translation towards Terra)** Oh, that one's a tasty morsel! [I'd love to get my tentacles around her...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NaughtyTentacles) 
**Ultros: (SNES translation towards Terra)** Delicious morsel! [Let me get my bib!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PredatorsAreMean)

[Weak to Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeakToFire): When you use a Fire spell on this aquatic creature...
QUOTE **Ultros:** Yeeeouch! Seafood soup is NOT on the menu!

tropeName: We Cannot Go On Without You
tropeNotes: [We Cannot Go On Without You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCannotGoOnWithoutYou): Enforces this. Ultros's first fight is generally not that difficult. Except for the fact that he at one point specifically targets Banon with a powerful attack because "your ugly mug gives me the creeps." And you're supposed to be protecting Banon during this fight. If he dies, it's game over.

[Working Off the Debt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorkingOffTheDebt): He is reduced to an NPC in the World of Ruin, now deeply in hock to the Dragon's Neck Coliseum. He literally can't afford to fight you anymore because he's lost so many battles that he now serves as their receptionist. Typhon will still bounce you from the Coliseum if you place a worthless item up for bet.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): In the climax of the second fight, he uses Humbaba Breath to blast away two party members.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): The final fight with Humbaba is between him and Esper Terra.
[Elemental Rock-Paper-Scissors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElementalRockPaperScissors): Is weak to Poison-elemental attacks in every appearance.
[Fixed Damage Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FixedDamageAttack): He has 1000 Needles for a guaranteed 1000 damage.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): A certain NPC describes him, along with Deathgaze and the Eight Dragons, as one of the ancient monsters of the world.

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): First fought by Terra, then by your party the first time you visit Mobliz. On your second visit, he is first fought by your party, then by Terra, who is permanently in Esper form for this battle, as well as the remnants of your party that weren't blown away by his Humbaba Breath.
[Rule of Three](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfThree): He finally dies in the third battle.
[Shock and Awe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShockAndAwe): He loves using lightning attacks, and he absorbs it as well.
[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild): Mobliz being inhabited entirely by children (the oldest other than Terra are only teenagers) does nothing to stop Humbaba attacking it.
[Blow You Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlowYouAway): He also attacks with Aero.
[Bowdlerise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bowdlerise): Changed to "Doomgaze" in the SNES translation, thanks to Nintendo's [Never Say "Die"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverSayDie) restrictions.
[Evil Is Deathly Cold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsDeathlyCold): As evidenced by his spells, which focus on Instant Death, Wind, and Ice.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): A certain NPC describes him, along with Humbaba and the Eight Dragons, as one of the ancient monsters of the world.

["Get Back Here!" Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetBackHereBoss): Flees after a few rounds of battle, but can't regenerate his HP after combat, so you can wear him down after repeated encounters. It's hard to track down a monster that could be anywhere in the world when you *have no way to tell where he may be*. You're going to be spending a lot of time flying around looking for him.
[Giant Flyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantFlyer): A huge flying enemy who wanders the world preying on people and is fought aboard the airship.
[An Ice Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnIcePerson): His main offensive spell is Blizzaga.

tropeName: Names to Run Away from Really Fast
tropeNotes: [Names to Run Away from Really Fast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToRunAwayFromReallyFast): Though the "gaze" part of the name is a bit out of place, the meaning of his full name is obvious.
[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): Even *Dissidia* remarks that how Bahamut's Magicite piece ended up in his mouth is something no one knows.
[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): Opens with Level 5 Death, and loves to spam the normal Death spell.

[Revive Kills Zombie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReviveKillsZombie): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). Despite its [skeletal appearance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkullForAHead), it's not technically undead, so this won't work. That being said, it is still weak to Holy and Fire like actual undead monsters are.
[Superboss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Superboss): A superboss in the game's original release, with end-game HP, loves to spam powerful magic, and drops a very powerful Magicite shard.

[Total Party Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalPartyKill): He opens every encounter with Level 5 Death, potentially wiping your group out before their first turn if they're all at a level multiple of 5.

[Deceptive Disciple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeceptiveDisciple): He was Duncan's loyal son and student, but prizes power above anything else, and betrayed and killed his master when he felt he had been shunned.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): For the second part of the fight with him, the other party members are blown away for Sabin to fight him one-on-one.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Sabin, as a fellow pupil to Duncan, but Vargas prizes power over discipline and honor.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Hitting him with a Blitz ends the fight instantly, as Vargas realizes Sabin knows more of Duncan's art than he does. Whether the Blitz kills him or convinces him to retreat is unclear.

tropeName: A Pupil of Mine Until He Turned to Evil
tropeNotes: [A Pupil of Mine Until He Turned to Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/APupilOfMineUntilHeTurnedToEvil): He was Duncan's son and best student, but he wanted command of the dojo and turned on his father when he thought Sabin was chosen over him. Sabin, however, claims Duncan had always intended for Vargas to be his successor; sadly, Vargas is too enraged to listen to reason by the time they confront each other.
